review_body: I contacted the hotel for the refund because of COVID 19 outbreak. The hotel responded promptly through travel agency and made the refund. Even though I booked through travel agency, I still receive dexceptional service. I will definitely return to this hotel

I usually like to stay in Ginza during my Tokyo trips as it is a central location and I can enjoy proximity to high street and uncountable number of eating and drinking options..But only challenging part about my choice is that it is difficult to get a decent spacious room at my budget. This time I was fortunate to get Hotel Monterey in my budget and this has been one of my best hotel stay in Ginza.The rooms are spacious (which is rare in Tokyo especially this area).Service is excellent.. The hotel staff is prompt and helpful.Location is good, surrounded by multiple eating outlets, 24 hrs convenience stores.It is a must recommended hotel for everyone wanting to stay in Ginza...

When I’m in Tokyo for business, I normally stay at a nearby international chain hotel and walk pass Hotel Monteray all the time. This time, I decided to give Hotel Monteray a try as I was intrigued by its decor.It is a pleasant surprise. Beside the excellent location, the room is spacious compare to similar hotels in Tokyo. And the shower is probably the best I have experienced in Tokyo, water is hot and strong.Front desk is efficient and pleasant.Price is excellent for the quality it offers. Highly recommended.

The hotel is located at a great place. Very close to major attractions, and subway station is under the building next to the hotel. The staff is very helpful and kind. The room is good size, very clean, and also with a desk and chair.

Our family of 4 stayed in the connecting rooms for 7 nights The rooms are small, which is pretty normal for Tokyo but it was more the fact that there was only a small cupboard with probably 6 hangers we could not unpack so needed to have the suitcases open and in the way. The furniture is chipped and sad looking and in need of replacement as well as the walls are scuffed and needing a fresh coat of paint, actually the whole of the hotel was in need of being freshened up! Only one rickety chair in the room so people tend to sit on the edge of the bed making it sag on one side, I found this very uncomfortable sleeping on a slope. Requested extra pillows before my arrival which they gladly supplied. The bathroom looks like it’s been renovated and had fantastic toiletries etc. Shower was great and hot water was instantaneous. No room safe. No foyer to speak of or seating area.No one helps with bags. The rooms are stuffy and got very hot, air-con didn’t work properly. Free bottled water daily. Many restaurants and shops around the hotel but are expensive being in Ginza. Strong signal Wi-Fi. Rooms were exceptionally clean. Provided pyjamas, which I would not wear they looked like hospital type. A couple of 24/7 convenience stores opposite the hotel.We booked this hotel at the last minute wanting interconnecting rooms, this hotel was the only one left at a reasonable price for Tokyo in a good area. I will look elsewhere next time unless they renovate.Show less

My family of 4 stayed in the connecting room and my brother stayed in a nearby room for 4 nights in total. The rooms are small, but normal for Tokyo I think. To put things into perspective, we hardly had room to place 2 large Samsonite suitcases and open them. But small rooms can be cozy and the the sleep was comfortable and quiet. There was a bathtub which is important, and wifi signal was strong. There is pay tv but the climate control was not great and we struggled to get the perfect temperature we liked. Thankfully there is a decent air purifier in each room to freshen up the environment. We never tried the breakfast as there are so many nice eating places around there, including decent coffee shops and a Natural Lawson convenience store right opposite the hotel. The hotel is 2-3 blocks away from the main Ginza shopping area and the nearest train station is Higashi Ginza. I think the price is reasonable for the Ginza area and we didn't have problems with the service. The hotel was busy but didn't give an overcrowded feeling, which I liked.

This must have been a great hotel when it would've opened and the place to be. But now it isn't as well maintained as it ought to be. If you can look past the little niggles, then it's a okay place to be. The location is to die for though.It's a shame because this place could really be top of the pops in Ginza.

review_body: The hotel is about 10 minutes walk from the central station.The room was comfortable, and larger than other hotel rooms we had elsewhere.We particularly liked the mobile phone available, so we could use it as sat nav, or to ring family who had another room.There was a good selection at breakfast.

It takes just one individual to ruin what could have been a good experience in a hotel. The individual in this case was a racist woman working the front desk at about 15:15 pm on Thursday, Nov. 7. My wife and I asked for information on how to get to Narita Airport using the Limousine Bus. The way she brusquely answered my questions and her haughty remark: “Why don’t you and your wife just walk 10 minutes to the bus stop to get the bus to the airport instead of taking a cab?” To which I replied, “I wish we could, unfortunately my wife could barely walk because of a badly sprained ankle.” Her response was to simply give me a bus schedule...She seemed to just want me and my wife to go away - and it occurred to me that she wanted to me move on so she can help a local Japanese guest. I wonder if she would have been more courteous and helpful if my skin color was WHITE??? It was disappointing that the great experience we’ve had thus far in Tokyo would be ruined by this ignorant person! Let me describe her for the readers of this review: she is Japanese, a woman with long black hair tied neatly and is about 5’ 6”. And as I mentioned she was on duty at the front desk at 5:15 pm on Nov. 7, 2019.

Blimey! Booked very last minute and as this hotel was ‘advertised’ as a ‘boutique hotel’ we went for it! Boutique in this sense means no facilities at all! No lobby area, no bar, no concierge, no room service! To be fair the room wasn’t too bad - toiletries etc provided with reasonable towels and slippers. No gown, no safe, very basic tea / coffee making facilities, one uncomfortable pillow and an ok ish mattress. Room was exceptionally clean and a reasonable size (a corner room with 4 windows and a view, the rest look tiny if the fire plan on the back of the door is anything to go by) with minimal storage space. It looks as if the rooms and corridors have been refurbished. Breakfast was ok with an omelette station, yogurt, tinned fruit (what’s that all about! Think 1970’s!) and good bakery items. The hotel is in a great position slap bang in the middle of Ginza. The metro station is only about 30 metres from the front door and about 20 mins walk to Tokyo station. We were only here for 4 nights with hand luggage, and this was not our first trip to Tokyo, so for us this wasn’t a problem. If you are a tourist and needing help and advice (in other words a concierge service) and room for luggage this would be hopeless in all honesty!

This hotel was lovely inside and out. The staff greeted me warmly. They were friendly and helpful. The room was spacious (by Tokyo standards), well appointed and clean. Robes and slippers were provided. The complimentary smart phone that comes with the room was extremely helpful for navigating Tokyo for my first visit. Very much appreciated! Breakfast was an interesting mix of western and Japanese breakfast with very helpful and attentive staff. It is also centrally located, close to many shops and restaurants. Also very close to the subway and only a 5-10 minute walk to Ginza station with luggage.

We had two adjoining rooms in this lovely hotel. Great location, convenient to transport and lots of great restaurants. Clean and bright, while slightly old-fashioned, we found it charming. The staff was wonderful and helpful.

The hotel was magnificent. The bathroom shower was to die for. The shower and bathtub had plenty of hot water. Really liked the portable phone and gps they gave you to use to find your way around town.

My wife and I stayed here for 4 nights. Slightly old fashioned hotel but very functional, bright, clean and good room size. We had a bed and breakfast deal and we both enjoyed the buffet breakfasts - very wide selection of English dishes ( they have Japanese options too) so we’ll fed at breakfast. We enjoyed the location which is short taxi ride from Tokyo station and less than 10 minute walk to the nearest JR station - Yamote line. There are closer subway stations in Ginza. We did use these as well as our JR pass but got away with buying single tickets when we needed them. We both loved Tokyo which is very clean, felt really safe and people very helpful. Tourist office does a great Tokyo guide book with maps (free) which I sometimes used to avoid carrying my Lonely Planet guide around. Would certainly recommend the hotel. Staff at reception very helpful and smiley.

The room is nice, clean and big enough for a couple and some space for large luggage arrangement. The staffs have good hospitality and are able to communicate effectively in English, convenient location.It is a small hotel so nothing much to do. If you just want to find a peaceful reasonably priced hotel to rest in Ginza area, this one will serve your need.

My friend & I shared a twin room on 13th floor. The room was so musty and stale when we walked in so we had them open the window. The A/C gave me terrible allergy probably due to it being old and dusty. The breakfast was ok, weird set-up and no gluten-free options. Over-priced for what it is.

Good hotel in the area of Ginza. The room was comfortable and big enough for two. They offered japanese and continental breakfast but not much choice only basically. Close to Ginza-Itchome underground station. There’re many convenient stores in surrounding.

I booked this hotel because I liked my November 2018 stay. However, there are a lot of changes from my previous booking which my Citi Prestige Concierge booked via Hotels.com. The room we stayed was so smelly and the sheets weren’t changed despite my request! My baby had created some stains on the linen and I was surprised to find the same stain on the same spot when I came back. The guy doing the cleaning just flipped the duvet :( So disappointed. I wonder if this was because I was offered a room upgrade for only 5K yen for 5 nights and I refused? Probably this room was really filthy to begin with :( I am very sad about this incident and I will not bringing the issue downstairs at the lobby because they will have a hard time understanding me. Thus, I am writing a review in text.

From the Qantas booking it looked delightful...elegant old world hotel..however..in reality .our first impression at the front desk was not so good. I have travelled japan and stayed in 6 different hotel chains. from Diaichi to mystay as well as ryokons so I know what good service in Japan looks like. the girls at the front desk when we booked in really could nt be bothered...the one who eventually served me had serious attitude. It was too painful to serve me...it didnt get any better. this hotel is frequented by japanese and asian travellers. other travellers were not welcome.The night staff gentleman when I had to go the red cross at ryponggi was very helpful. my son had broken his leg. other than that we were not given any assistance. We had to leave the hotel 3 nights in advance and I was told very clearly that I wasnt getting a refund even though I hadnt asked. A man behind the desk also told me if I check out I cant come back. then demanded I pay 410yen for the phone call made that morning..(to qantas)...all in all if you are a foreigner try mitsui gardens or my stay.on the up side just across the road two great little convenience stores.super friendly a drug store as well. and some great bars.

This is an older hotel with bigger rooms than the newer hotels in Japan. The check in/out process was quick. The staff members were pleasant and polite as all Japanese are - yes, we encountered the most polite group of people among all groups on our travels. During our ten day trip to Japan, we did not encounter one Japanese person who had an attitude problem. Everyone was calm and amazingly polite. Everyone from hotel staff, clerks at stores, restaurant servers, employees at train stations, etc... were courteous.Back to the hotel...they let you leave your luggage at the front desk for free after check out if you have a later flight. The hotel is a short walk from Tokyo station which makes it convenient to catch the Narita Express to the airport. There are many shops nearby; however, clothing in these shops were extremely pricey. Restaurants in this area were more expensive than in other areas of Tokyo as well. We were lucky to find two reasonably priced restaurants that served excellent sushi in this area.Overall, the hotel is decent for the price we paid.

Located in the CBD, it is an older style, renovated hotel with medium sized rooms. The room temperature was too hot for our liking with the a/c controlled remotely by hotel with no user adjustment. The beds were comfortable, although the pillows were too soft for our liking. A Good breakfast was included with a large variety of both Japanese and Western foods. Free bottled water supplied in room along with free WiFi with a reasonable speed. The shower was over the bath. The bath has high sides which would be an issue for those with mobility or balance issues. A good range of toiletries were included.

Reasonable value for a Tokyo hotel in a quiet part of Ginza. Shops and restaurants are in the surrounding area. Good shower, comfortable bed, smallish room. Staff held our bags after checkout, which was handy as we had an evening flight. Windows do not open, which would have been nice to let some fresh air in. There is a metro station nearby but the line isn't as useful as the Ginza line which is a little further away and connects to Tokyo station.

The hotel is located in a small quiet side street in the district of Ginza. Restaurants, bars and shops are just around the corner. The Metro is only 2 minutes away. A good starting position to discover Tokyo. The rooms are sufficiently large and clean. The staff is friendly. But there is no bar. The rooms are a little bit sensitive (Lodness). WLAN and an own "tablet" with internet and telephone is freely available in every room. We didn't have breakfast, we rather went to the numerous cafes directly in the surroundings. Good hotel. Gladly again.

I stayed here while attending a conference in Tokyo at the International Tokyo Forum. I is about 10 minutes walk to the conference centre which is very convenient. Also about 20 minutes walk to the main Tokyo station. The location is a highlight, as its close to the main shopping area of Ginza. The hotel is a bit older but the rooms are bigger and not as cramped as some other hotels I've stayed at in Tokyo. I also realized a lot of people stay here including tour groups, so sometimes it can take a bit of a wait to use the lifts and there may be a wait at breakfast. The buffet breakfast is great though with both western and Japanese options. Also an omelette station where the chefs cook big fluffy omelettes fresh.

A typical business style hotel in Tokyo near the Ginza. Clean and accommodating, but not particularly large. The main selling feature is location. It is easy walking distance from Tokyo station and a similar walking distance from the centre of the Ginza. The ability to walk to Tokyo station is a real win on a first night in Tokyo after a trans-Pacific flight. But there are better 'home base' locations to be a tourist.

The Hotel Monterey in Ginza is a business hotel that is showing its age. Furniture is chipped, doors hang crooked, and paint is no longer fresh. The lobby area is a pretty somber affair. Like many hotels of this price category, a lot of rooms face a wall immediately opposite the hotel.Internet is unreliable and slow. But the hotel has two redeeming factors: breakfast is a cut above most business hotels in this price category, with lots of variety and fresh produce. And for people looking to stay in Ginza, the location just steps away from all of the shops is hard to beat.

This hotel has a very good location near shopping centres and restaurants. There is a corner shop opposite the hotel.Rooms are small, beds ok. Breakfast was good. The tap water is good, but you also get every day a water bottle from the hotel.

Hotel was in nice location and looks nice at first appearance. When you check in they want you to pay in full upfront. If this was a hostel I understand but for a hotel charging 200 USD a night and claiming to be 4 star this is low class. They offer no western English TV channels and only have a local Japan news channel with English speakers but you get the same 4 news stories on recorded loop. I figured it would be best to just sleep but the pillows have plastic covers under the cases and one side is almost solid and feels like it is filled with solid dense plastic balls. I woke up with terrible neck pain from this. The staff is ambivalent to any complaint and just stare at you as if to say you have no right to expect a decent room with normal amenities. To top it off, they wanted another cash deposit to borrow a power cord adapter to plug in my cord.I strongly urge anyone looking at this property book the Mercure right next door which is so much nicer.

Recently spent just over a week here with my husband and 2 teenage sons. We had connecting rooms, each with double beds. Were very impressed with the cleanliness of the rooms. The bathroom came fully stocked with bodywash, shampoo, conditioner, toothbrushes, shaving blades and combs. The 2 free bottles of water per room each day were great! The rooms are small, but perfectly adequate and we were out most of the day so only came back to the room each day after dinner to sleep.The free pajamas and slippers to use for our stay were a nice touch too. We were given free mobile phones to use during the length of our stay were were a great way of staying in touch with each other and being able to find our way around the city with google maps.We had no problems on arrival via Narita Express getting a taxi from Tokyo Station and found check-in speedy. The reception staff spoke good english. Ginza is wonderful palce to stay as a lot quieter than many of the other suburbs like Shinjuku and Shibuya. I would recommend eating dinner elsewhere though as Ginza can be pricey. Otherwise try some of the back alleys in Ginza as some cheap tasty little tempura and noodle places away from the fancy brand stores. There is a handy Family Mart convenience story just over the road from the hotel for snacks and drinks. We explored most of Tokyo by train and it was very easy to catch the Yamanote line train back to Yurakucho station which is a 5 minute walk to the hotel. Would definitely stay here again as great location and and a nicely serviced basic hotel that suit our needs to a tee.

This hotel has a perfect location for shopping and eating. The room is cleaned, very close from transportation and they lend you for free a mobile phone during your stay! The price was very decent as well. Highly recommend you to stay here.

I bring a 4months old baby, the hotel provides free babycot which is very useful. The room is also quite spacey, we travel with 3 big luggage, a stroller and a few cabin bags, the room can accommodate our stuffs and still has space for the babycot! (plus the staff helped us carry our luggage to our room) the location is also fabulous, there are Lawson n family mart just across the street and ginza shopping street and subway station is also only 5 minutes away.

Excellent location with lots of choices for dining and many art galleries to visit in this elegant area. The French stye building offers a very nice standard of accomodation. An excellent restaurant downstairs.

I travel to Tokyo regularly. The Monterey I've used twice already with all of positive impressions. At the front desk welcomes you alway friendly smiley face. Facts that the front desk area is rather small and sometimes can get crowded, suitaces are left by the guest who are checking out and leaving their belongings while still sightseeing. But if you skip that fact nothing to complain.The rooms are perfectly fine for me (although I am 5'6''). Two simple beds, TV , fridge etc. I could say that for this price I would expect something more but it's Ginza 1-Chome so the centre of the city so I presume that's ok. The amenities are very good however, the bath tube is small even for me. The close distance for shops, restaurances, pubs is I think the key for this hotel. But overall if I would have to spent my own money I would search for different option.

Our family, being frequent guests at your Hotel Monterey Kyoto, we expected the same if not better of your Ginza Monterey. But we were totally wrong! We suggest you tetrain or change your entire front desk crew as they have shown zero passion in their job. It’s the first time we see front desk staff with NO SMILES, making us all feeling unwelcomed, showing no interests to render assists in any way. It’s unbelievable that we find such low service standard in Japan as we deem Japanese to have the best attitude and render world class service. But today it all changed as we encountered the worst of attitudes. We should have stick to Marriott Courtyard! We come Japan often and today Monterey staff have brought service standard in Japan down the drain. Disappointing!!

We stayed here for 3 nights in 2 adjoining rooms.Small rooms but everything you need. PJ's supplied! Buffet breakfast very good. Staff friendly and helpful.Central location, surrounded by high end shops. If you dont like air con you can get the staff to open the window in your room for fresh air.Lots of more med-high end restaurants in the area but it would seem that dinner reservations are essential.We struggled to find a table near Tokyo Square when we were looking one evening at about 830pm .Not many smaller cheaper eateries around as in some of the other suburbs we encountered.Of note smoking is still allowed in some restaurants which can be stifling if you get caught between 2 smoking tables.Small convenience stores across the street.Overall an enjoyable stay.

The Hotel Monterey Ginza is quite an unique hotel in the Ginza district. First of all, the hotel's main structure has that classical look, but the amenities in the guest room are quite modern. Each room comes with a pre-configured Android smartphone that has unlimited 4G data and voice over IP. You can even use it for international calling. All facilities, including the guest rooms are clean. The staffs were very helpful to me. I was there almost 3 hours earlier than their official check-in time, but they let me check in and go into my room anyway. If I have to complain, it is the location. While it is not very far from the nearest stations, it took about 10 to 15 minutes to walk to them. Well, technically there's a Ginza-itchōme Station just across the street, but it's on the Yurakucho Line, which isn't very useful for tourists or visitors, unless your only plan is to go to Ikebukuro. Don't get me wrong, though, at the price you are paying for this hotel, you won't regret walking.

Five stars for location - within walking distance to the center of Ginza, surrounded by restaurants, across a Family Mart with easy access to the subway. A nice feaure is the “handy” phone which was offered complimentary during your stay with free local & international calls & Wifi. However, all other services are minimal. The reception area is a counter with a couple of chairs. They don’t provide money exchange services nor would they make a restaurant reservation. The rooms are small - as expected - though impeccably clean.

Very helpful staff quickly solved a problem with our booking and were always friendly and helpful throughout our 6 night stay.Our rwin room was a reasonable size and large by Tokyo standards and larger than a double room..Monterey Hotel is close to the Ginza department stores and the Metro.The breakfast buffet had a large range, including an egg and omelettte station.Even better was Escale Restaurant for dinner. Superb!

Great location - in the center of Ginza. Reasonable price. Not too fancy but good value for the money. Breakfast was very good - enough variety of Japanese and Western style of food. They don’t have full range of amenities (for example - there is no concierge service) but free cell phone in the room to use during the stay really surprised me. If you don’t want overpay for your stay in such expensive city as Tokyo this hotel is recommended

I understand that everyone has different expectations with Hotels, restaurants etc however after having stayed at this hotel 20 odd years ago, when it certainly was not any better than 4 stars, decided to stay again as I was travelling with a friend on a budget. We paid around $240.00 Australian a night.It is now about a 2.5 star hotel!The reception area was enough to set the scene on arrival....very tired, littered with suitcases and 2 chairs, not lounge chairs but old dilapidated "dining" type chairs.Then when we got to our rooms, not carpeted but wooden floors that needed a good mop and 2 single beds in each room. Also very old tired fit out. The hotel for the money is due for a much needed make over. On leaving for dinner the first of our 3 night stay, I asked one of the receptionists if they would book a Japanese restaurant for the next evening for us. She said that she was unable to do this as they had no concierge service. What hotel at that price cannot book a restaurant? Totally unsatisfactory. Overall a very unpleasant experience. Staff need a real kick to get them going. Hotel needs a good paint.

This is a well kept older hotel only a couple blocks from all of the restaurants and shopping in Ginza. You are right next to a subway station. There is a Food Mart right across the street for quick snacks, a light meal or a Coca Cola. We went there several times to save money on food.They take check in time seriously so don't expect to have a room ready if you arrive early. They did hold our luggage and it was a short walk to a mall area where we browsed around until our room was ready.

This is a small and cosy hotel, located at the inner lane of the famous Ginza area. Even though the rooms are small but it comes with complete amenities and complimentary WiFi too. He elevator is unique, especially the level indicator that moves according to the level of the floor. There are many eateries surrounding the hotel vicinity. The hotel is approximately 5 minutes walk to Matsuya department store.

As the title said, useful position in ginza, close to the shopping street of ginza and near to yarakucho station where you can take train of yanamote line.Breakfast is very good with japanese & continental choices.

This is a difficult one to rate, specially since last year I stayed in the hotel across the street. First, one has to admit that the location of both is unbeatable, in the center of Ginza. Second, compared to the other hotel, this one has an amazing breakfast buffet that one cannot simply oversee (it is pretty good indeed). Third, a very nice detail is that they provide guests with a free mobile phone with sone serious data. This is a nice perk. Finally, service in both hotels is attentive and extremely courteous (Japanese style I guess). Now the cons, when it comes to the rooms Monterrey Ginza hotel simply falls short. I understand the tiny spaces, after all this is Japan not Cancún, but the rooms looked tired and dated. The TV is tiny and old, the decor screams 1990s and overall the use of spaces is odd. In that regard, the hotel across the street has invested some serious money in room development compared to this one. I wish I could give three and a half stars (because of the perks) but unfortunately I can’t.

Hotel is located in Ginza - a great location easy walk to several Metro lines and was comparatively affordable for our family of 4. Amazing shopping and restaurants nearby. The rooms were a little small, however they offer connecting rooms (which seem quite hard to find in Tokyo) so our family of four fit very comfortably. Each room had twin beds, decent sized wardrobe, a tv with some English language movies available to purchase and a smallish bathroom. Breakfast was included and was very good. Hotel was busy, yet was quiet. It is a little aged but has a bit of character and the staff were very helpful. A great place to stay!

I think the Reception Area set the tone. Untidy , with luggage of customer all over, the entrance difficult to locate & below-par lift close by. It was further compounded by their refusal to allow early check-in despite having emailed our need earlier. the funny part was that they were ready to give the rooms if we paid extra 300 yens. We would not have minded at all if the rooms were not available abinitio. The staff was unyielding despite our requests.Be that as it may , the Hotel can boast of good location with main Ginza street walking distance away.. It was quite easy to locate.The room was small as to be expected in Tokyo. It was sparsely furnished with just one chair. Bit of a joke, I gather.. Bed was OK But storage space was a bit too less. Most TV channels had Japanese programme going so it was Latin for us. Bathroom , expectedly small but had all toiletteries .WC seat was ultra-modern with total hands-free operation. A definite plus , here. Top floor gives a great look of the city , thus getting another plus. Air-conditioning was centrally controlled so we had to live it.Braekfast was served in nice restaurant hall with adequate seatting capacity. Breakfast was OK more for the Japanese than us as most dishes catered to their taste. No cheese, pastries, limited fruits. No eggs to order. Coffee & tea were nice. Yes, they make you wait before you get a seat after getting a No from them. I personally feel this is highly avoidable as the tables & seting were adequate.Over all our three day-stay in the Hotel was just satisfactory considering the the Hotel claims to be Four Star. I will not give it more than THREE.

It's just an Okay hotel, quite close to the subway station and you can find a lot of restaurants and shops around. The room was too small, which is normal for Japan, but when you have difficulties opening two suitcases at once, you just sigh and tell yourself "It's ok, we will spend here only 3 nights..."The bathroom was clean but old, shower head was super old but the pressure was strong. I guess it's fine to stay there for a night or two but probably not more than that.

It’s a 15 minute walk from the train station. On the walk, you see the famous Ginza shopping district in all its glory with its high end shops. Our hotel was located near the outskirts of the Ginza but still nice. The hotel is on the older side and is showing its age. The desk people are very respectful but don’t speak too much English. No concerige service and the staff was hit and miss with trying to provide help. They made reservations for us once but on a second occasion, we’re told they didn’t make restaurant reservations! Not a high level of service. It’s close to transportation and convenient walking distance to a LOT of high end shopping.

Good value for money. In Ginza but in a very quiet location. Close to Tokyo Station, metro,shopping and restaurants. The rooms were small but clean and comfortable.I found the concierge services reasonably helpful.

Coming from Dubai I expected that this Hotel i choose in the most high end district in Tokyo to be mind blowing, however it was way less than what I had in mind. - Room size is small , window no view (literally looking into back of some buildings)- The bed and pillow no comfortable at all.- The reception / concierge were not that helpful being first time in Tokyo as an arab solo girl I expected more assistance and consideration to the questions (I was waiting for the girl who asked me to wait & went to another guests assisting them (I think they were Asians) after standing there , I just gave up and walked away. - Upon check out another girl once I handed over the key simply said : ok thank you , good bye) I was like wait just give me assistance about the airport pick up / shuttle bus. Just handed over to me a black & white and said that’s the one , ok!. They just have no time! Again, this is a 4 Star in most sophisticated area in Tokyo aka Ginza ... unfortunately last impression they left me with was very disappointing!

This hotel is close to good shopping restaurants and the metro. The room we had was smallish but adequate. It was great to be able to open the window. (Ask the staff to unlock it).The decor is art deco-- loved it.The lifts are slow and the break fast room rather chaotic at times.The helpfulness of the staff varied considerably.Would stay again as really enjoyed the area and would find no reason to try another hotel in the Ginza. We were with a group of about 16 people and the only negative was there is no bar or coffee lounge to sit and chat.

Stayed here due to various factors - wanting to be on the east side, nice surroundings, near Tokyo station. Its down a side street and we got a taxt with our luggage on the first morning due to jet lag! Was only ¥800 and worth it. We couldnt check in till 3pm but they held our bags until then. Rooms smallest of our holiday but everthing you need. Only issue is using the lifts at peak time. When we were checking out (to get a train) it took a while to get in one. One lady said it took her 20 mins to get downstairs. Maybe they should think about letting people use thee emergency stairs as this would free up the lifts? So leave plenty of time to get out if leaving about 8.30am.

As my favorite hotel in Ginza was fully booked, I chose Hotel Monterey Ginza. I stayed there with my friend for 8 nights in December. The location of the hotel was perfect for shopping and dining. The room size was just fine for Japan standard, especially Tokyo. However, I found the service standard unacceptable. The reception staff refused to help make dining reservation. I have never experienced this with other hotels in Tokyo. My friend left her purse at a cafe. She tried to call the cafe to check but the staff there did not understand English. She went to the hotel reception for help. Again the reception staff refused but finally gave in after we strongly insisted and emphasized the communication problem.

Great location, delicious japananese food for breakfast, clean & convenient room. Size of the room: it is a bit small, but still ok. The staffs are also very nice . We would like to stay here again someday.

We were bargain hunting for our very last minute visit to Tokyo and thought we would go for a luxury room advertised at Monterey at a substantial discount. The room ended up being a par-for-the course hotel room, so not the great deal we were expecting. Maybe we just haven't grasped some aspect of the system, but we were pretty sure the room did not come with the features promised.Other than that, a perfectly fine stay. Helpful staff, very handy location, and typical hotel amenity. It's just missing that stand out "something" (e.g. a comfortable lounge area, historic features, pool access).

Room is pretty spacious for 2 person with 2 medium size luggage. I like the hotel amenities, it's so complete and they add new every day. Walking distance to many option of station (subway or tokyo station). Walking distance to Ginza main street. Near mini market. There's food choice too nearby. Overall I like to stay in this hotel again.

The hotel is near Ginza main street and easy to access from Tokyo station (taxi fare: ~ 700-900 JPY). The room is small but clean and the staff is very helpful and friendly, their English is adequate.

Hotel Monterey Ginza is very handily situated being near 2 subway stations and a 15 minute walk from Tokyo main station. Ginza is a great place to stay in Tokyo. The hotel is old fashioned (1950s) but stylish and the breakfast room is very attractive with an OK breakfast. My only disappointment was the beds. The beds and pillows were hard and some people think that is good for you, but I don't. I don't think you should have to be stoic to go to bed.

Staying at this hotel is like staying the center of Ginza. A few steps away there is an entrance to the Ginza Itchome subway station of Yurakucho line. It is very close to many department stores Ginza has to offer. Ginza subway station of Marunouchi, Ginza and Hibiya lines is also 5 min away. It was super convenient for shopping and sightseeing. The room was clean, neat and comfortable size. I should have chosen a breakfast package but there is a convenience store where you get some food for breakfast. This is a nice hotel to stay.

Booked the place a week before arrival. Located in the heart of posh Ginza. Many train stations nearby. Close to most renowned shopping malls in Ginza. The hotel is very well maintained, super friendly and helpful staffs and speaks English. The room is spotless with free WiFi and they provide an android phone for free local calls, navigation and surfing net. But we already purchased our roaming card from airport. We booked a smaller room as we will go out in daytime comes back only when it’s late. The toilet with heated toilet seat and small long bath with powerful water spray and good temperature adjustment. All toiletries are provided.All in all, a very good experience staying here. Will definitely come back on my next trip to Tokyo.

I stayed here with my friendIt was absolutely lovely hotel All the staffs in this hotel were really kind and nice they helped me a lot Also infront of the hotel there are 2 convenient stores u can buy nearly everything in there! Also Ginza where the hotel is has everything u need shopping & nice restaurants. I would love to stay here again such a lovely hotel the room was very clean too !

Close to the heart of Ginza this hotel is well located for access to the Ginza district and all its eateries. It’s also within easy walking distance to Tokyo Station if you are wanting to venture further afield. The hotel is very well maintained and room service, as in cleaning, etc, is first class. Our room was very small however with barely enough leg room either side of the queen size bed. The usual modular bathroom/toilet which is common in Japan was the ensuite. Again small but functional. I have to save though my partner and I are average sized adults. Larger people may struggle for room. The only other negative is the air-conditioning. In short, the in room air conditioning doesn’t work. Some sort of central air-conditioning prevailed and it kept the room too hot and stuffy. We had to call room service to unlock a window so we could open it to let cooler air in. That in turn let in the city noise. Not good. So unless you put up with the noise you can close the window and expect a fairly hot nights sleep.

We stayed 3 nights at the hotel. The atmosphere is good with well trained and friendly staf. Room was good, bed ok, cushion a bit small and hard for western style though. Breakfest was very complete with continuous fresh supply. The only negatieve element is that all guest movement depended on 2 lifts only which at rush hours easily results in waiting time and/or very crowded space in the lift. A pity that the staircases can only be used in case of emergency.

Relatively reasonable price considering its location. It was close from Tokyo station, 760 yen by taxi. I could walk if I didn't have any suitcase. Inside was very nice. Very friendly to the foreigners with many English signs. Front desk personnel were very nice and helpful. Will stay again.

This hotel was in a high end shopping area with lots of variety. The hotel was in a lovely older style building but the inside was clean, modern & has everything needed.The buffet breakfast was great with every breakfast food provided both Japanese & Western. Lots of restaurants & convenience stores close by, walking distance to the train & the best coffee with a real espresso machine just around the corner!! A great choice for the last night of a busy exciting trip.

As we were staying a week in tTokyo we wanted good value and location a. The main problemnd Monterey Ginza seemed to provide this. Rather cold attitude on checkin given no information about facillities. On 12th floor room quiet small as expected but storage nonexistent no drawers just a small basket and tiny wardrobe. we had to hunt for kettle and tea and cofee tray, However the room was spotlessly clean we did notmind the hard bed but no extra pillows The main problem is no lounge or bar so you are tied to the small room. Plenty of convenience stores across the road which we used for drinks location is everythind near to shopping station and other areas. We would not stay here again unless they upgraded facillities for guest comfort but we got what we paid for ie locationinGinza

Hotel is next door to Ginza luxury shopping streets, great variety of restaurants and within easy access to the fast metro- and railroad system. Rooms are well kept, clean and of adequate size. Bathroom has soaps, shampoos, lotions and other amenities - what a treat. Breakfast enjoyable, service of a very good Japanese standard. Area is safe to wander around even in the late hours of the day.

We stayed in Tokyo for one night to catch Shinkansen to Osaka on the next morning. The location is a bit far away from Tokyo Station, at least 15mins walk down to the hotel. Hotel is nice and my friend's room is out of expected. Their room is very big with sofa area. The staff gave us a wrong room which is not matched with the room that I booked, but they changed it immediately and did the apologies. Bath amenities are brilliant.

Staff were brilliant. Stored our bags at 9am when we arrived so we could go exploring. Located close to (high end) shops. Many great restaurants, including a very affordable bib gourmand Korean restaurant. And a Maccas! Stations all round it, including Tokyo for bullet trains to Kyoto. Close to fish market too. Room is unbelievably clean. A bit less character than the building itself, which is beautiful. Really only just big enough for 2. You do spend a lot of time out. And for the price relative to alternatives, this seems a great option for those that need to be at this end of town.

Small hotel in a great location of Ginza. Value for money for the location. Room was ok size compared to many hotels I have stayed in, in Japan so I was pleasantly surprised at how spacious it actually was!! It has recently been renovated. Very comfortable room, good beds and nice bathrooms. Staff polite and helpful. Lift was quirky to the eye but crazy slow in the mornings, so allow yourself plenty of time!! Breakfast was such a let down. I have never had to queue for breakfast in a hotel!!!! I was there on a business trip and wanted to get in and out but there was a queue and this obviously wasn't unusual as there were chairs lined up outside! You had to have a coupon (when someone turned up without one an older couple the staff were not that friendly to them about it). Then they eventually showed you to a table and presented you with a tacky plastic cafeteria tray with a plate, cutlery and a cheap nasty serviette!! What a disgrace! Sitting in a large room that was decorated opulently with chandeliers and table cloths and a plastic cafeteria tray!!!! The tables were large and room layout was poor. A bit of proper design and the room could easily fit more people very comfortably and still look nice. There was an overflow room the next morning - yet I still had to queue. That room was so brightly lit and poor layout I really did feel I was sitting in a cafeteria. The food was... "okay" quite average. I had told myself if I had to queue the next day I wasn't as the food was not worth it. But there was only one person so I waited. The last day I didn't bother. It was a real shame, it was their biggest let down. I would stay again but would skip breakfast.

Size of 3 star hotels" room size is a general issue so, this hotel is no exception in rhat regard.The hotel is rather old compared to other hotels in the neighborhood.The decoration is also very modest.İn the end, just plain and functional with good distance to Ginza.

Small boutique hotel located in the heart of Ginza. The team were extremely polite and helpful our room was small . We booked well in advance to get a very competitive rate.The reception team focused on the up sell to guests trying to sell an early check in and room upgrade. The room was well maintained and serviced although a little too small for two people. The Japanese welcome and service were true to form, outstanding. We will stay there again without question. Thank you all for a great job well done.

I stayed ayer the Ginza Monterrey Hotel five nights and I liked it! The hotel is very conveniently located in the heart of Ginza, a chic neighbourhood in Tokyo.Rooms are small but comfortable. TV with some international channels, coffee maker and safe deposit.Very attentive staff. Reasonable price

Excellent location, just 2 blocks from ginza Main Street and kabuki theater. Subway station also very close. Lobby too small, no seating area. Rooms big enough for Japanese standards. Breakfast includes some international staff like croissant and omelette.

We stayed for three nights at the Monterey in Ginza. if you want a hotel that is virtually silent at night (and the day for that matter), this is it.The hotel has an old fashioned charm and character, with good service and an extensive European/Asian buffet breakfast.The beds were typically Japanese and on the firm to hard side. the rooms bigger than we expected for the rate and the area we were in (Ginza district).also a good range on Japanese and non-Japanese eateries within walking distance.

Stayed here a few days before we choose to have the breakfast buffet, not included with our room. Food OK but the service was odd. Took away our plate and utensils and had to retrieve our own. They knew they made a mistake, we told them, but didn't bother to fix it or apologize

This hotel was our last stop for my two week trip in Japan. It might be the nostalgia talking, but this wasn't the worst hotel but it wasn't my favorite either. Middle of the road was about right. The best thing about staying here is the location. A few hundred feet from the rail system and restaurants and within walking distance to a Starbucks. My companions I stayed one night and were able to get safely back after a night on the town by Taxi with no problem.The beds were firm and the rooms were clean. With this being reasonably priced I think you definitely get your money's worth. The hotel staff seemed extremely busy the first and next day we checked out...this must have been one of the more popular places to stay in Tokyo due to the location.

Stayed in this hotel for 3 nights during our 21days tour in Japan. (2nights upon arrival in tokyo, and 1night before leaving tokyo back to our home country).Booked the hotel via agoda with extremely good deal. It is only about USD 80 per night for a double room. Wanted to stay near tokyo station as I am using JR train to/from Narita airport. Room was slightly bigger if compared to other hotel in Tokyo. Old classic outdoor design, complete room amenities. The only bad point was its centralized aircon. During winter, the hotel was under heater mode throughout whole night. Window cant be opened and hence it was a little stuffy/warm at night.The hotel was about 6min walk from JR Yurakucho, and about 15min walk from Tokyo station. The hotel didn't leave me with any impression and if i were to choose again, I will choose other hotel should I need to stay around Tokyo station

I usually stay in Mercure hotel which is right in across the road of this hotel.But this time I had to use Monteray Ginza because Mercure was almost full.The two hotels provided almost same level of breakfast and room size but their service level and atmosphere were quite different. I asked the receptionists small favors which were possible in Mercure but there were nothing possible in Monteray. Although Mercure is slightly more expensive than Monteray, I would definitely stay in Mercure and if Mercure has no rooms available, I would stay somewhere else other than Monteray

I stayed four nights qt the Monterey Ginza and I recommend this hotel.The location is perfect, right in the heart of Ginza, the most elegant area of Tokyo.The hotel is not far from the Narita Airport Express bus (20 min walk or 10 min taxi).The rooms are not big ( Tokyo standard) but have everything you need: confortable bed and pillows, coffee maker, flat screen tv ( no international channells!!) free wifi, bathroom with a lot of amenities. No safe deposit box on the room. Only available at the reception.Helpful staff with sufficient english at the reception .We arrived at 2 pm and our room was already available, although check in time was 3pm.The price was reasonable for Japans standards, location and quality.

Nice Hotel in the middle of Ginza. Close to subway, restaurants, shopping and main train station. Hotel is a bit dated but very clean and friendly staff. Nice Japanese breakfast buffet (rice, miso soup, broiled fish, eggs...) Reasonable room rates

Good location. Not too far from Tokyo station. Ginza is pretty good for westerners. More relaxed, more western, more western food.Clean, safe but small. Bathrooms are good quality. Has good wifi. She'll do.

The location is great as it's a manageable 15-20min walk to Tokyo Station. The surrounding streets are lively with high end fashionable shopping and plenty of dining options. The rooms were reasonable in size and the bathroom had a great shower with good water pressure and lots of heat. We were fortunate in that there was no external noise overnight and we ended up sleeping well, despite the weird pillows that were 'normal' consistency on one side and an odd 'massage ball' texture on the other. There were toiletries provided as well which was a nice touch.Staff may have had minimal English on some shifts but they always did their best to be helpful and we had a few giggles with them when we tried to use a Google Translate app to ask some questions - my suitcase had been destroyed in transit and a new one was meant to be delivered whilst the loan bag from the airport was to be collected. Trying to make sure the hotel would accept the delivery was almost comical but it all worked out in the end.

Hotel was ideally located, close to metro and busy areas. The room was very clean but on the smaller size, as expected in Japan. Staff could have been a little more helpful in recommending restaurants and other inquiries we had. Not memorable but does the trick. Would stay again.

As compared to other Japanese hotels, our room was pretty good - 20 sqm, clean and comfortable. Metro is right beside the hotel. Several restaurants are easily accessible around the area, just walking distance. Front Desk staff provided very good service. Highly recommend.

This hotel is not for people who want to spend a lot of time in their room. It is very clean comfortable, but the room is small by western standards.It is in the heart of the Ginza and walkable with a roll on from Tokyo Main Station.

Unbongout
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed here for 3 days in April. The room was small with limited storage, but it was sufficient for our short stay. The main issue with the room was that it was very warm, and despite asking for a non-smoking room, there was a strong smell of smoke. There is no way to control the temperature in the room and the windows are locked, but we were able to have them come up and unlock the window, which made it bearable. The front desk staff was very kind and helpful, and the location couldn't be better.

The hotel excists a while an the front of it shows that. We liked it because it gives a more warm welkome then the sterile, modern entrances of businesslike hotels today. The people at the desk are friendly and spreak english very Well. Hotelroom was big enough and had all the necessities you need in a hotel. The airconditioning worked well and that is necessary because the window could not be opened without the help of a staff member. Metro is just outside the hotel and the JR station is within a 10 minute walk.

We stayed three nights. A very clean and comfortable hotel. The staff were very nice and welcoming. We had easy access to public transit. The room was larger than I imagined it would be. Would definitely stay here again.

This is a basic hotel in the heart of Ginza. Got there and room was really stuffy and had a stale smoke smell. The air purifier (doubles as air con?) took a good hour to warm up. We had to ask to open the window as it was so hot! With the window open, you're totally fine.Bed and pillow both firm, supportive and surprisingly good.Nice Art Deco touches across the hotel like the manual dial in the elevators.Positives1. They provided a baby cot free of charge. 2. Really strict front desk vault access procedure. You're stuff is safe with them. Negatives - 1. they refused to make a restaurant booking for us which we found very surprising.If you can get a good price, go for it. Otherwise give it a miss.

We stayed only one night. The hotel is clean and the beds are comfortable. The decor is old and chipped and the facilities are basic. I am not sure it is really 4 star, I would say 3. It is in a really good spot in Ginza so that is a plus. We did not eat at the hotel, too many tempting places nearby!

If you are looking for a large modern hotel with room service then this is not for you! It's a small hotel with a European feel. Clean, comfortable bed but the pillows!@#...... like rocks. The hotel is in a quiet street off Ginza Street and central to everything. The double room was a reasonable size for Japan. Friendly, helpful staff. If they upgraded their pillows I would stay again!!!

We booked this hotel because we messed up our hotel booking and booked 1 night short in our original hotel. We chose this hotel as it was just across the road from our original hotel.We were not disapointed with our choice. Although the hotel is older, the rooms are just as big if not bigger than the previous hotel. Amenities are older but service is as good.I prefer the bed in this hotel and pillows are feather and down. Love it or hate it, depending on your preference.Location wise, right smack in the premier shopping district with numerous subway and train stations within 10 minutes walking distance.Convenience stores can be found just across the street and many foodjoints and restaurants nearby to suit any budget. We almost always have our dinner at Yurakucho, below the JR train track before going back to the hotel.Although we will choose our previous because it is newer, this hotel is also highly recommended for the size of the rooms (Tokyo standards) and convenience of l9cation with food, shopping and public transportation nearby.Oh yes, rooms are clean and maintenace of the rooms is up to mark.

Hotel is ideally located in the Ginza* 10 mins walk to Tokyo station * 5 mins walk to Ginza metro line* Great shower/deep bath/toiletries * Breakfast buffet (western & Japanese)* French restaurant * Helpful but unobtrusive staff* smoking/non-smoking rooms* Close proximity to many restaurants /bars/convenience stores* Luxury shopping all around

We had 2 nights here and it served as a great base to explore Tokyo. The area was fantastic we could walk to the train stations, shopping strip and fish market easily. The hotel staff were so nice and professional, the room was great, comfy bed - we slept so well. The breakfast blew us away. Felt super fancy and absolutely delicious food options. Would stay here again, thanks!
