Putt V
Bangkok, Krung Thep, Thailand

review_body: Stayed here overnight when we arrived in Tokyo on route to Takayama. The staff were very helpful and the breakfast was very good. The downside was the room size and the double bed which was fairly small and not very comfortable.In fairness to the hotel we were attracted by their website and the very reasonable tariff for Tokyo. As the title says you get what you pay for.We subsequently cancelled our further five night stay at the hotel on our way back home and we're impressed by the professional attitude of their reservations manager. I believe now from staying at other hotels in Japan that you need to spend more for a comfortable stay than we had budgeted for. Our thanks to the hotel for their understanding.

Location is the key here. Service was basic. Rooms were very warm as we Approached End autumn. Heaters were turned on instead of aircons. We turned them off and had the staff open the windows for us. Rooms very very tight.

as often pictures look much better on the web site. Very tiny double bedroom but not really unusual in Tokyo. A/C was not working so the only way to get some cool air was to ask for the window ti be opened and then you get the noise coming from the street...Nickname of the hotel should be the "1000 yen hotel": if you check in earlier than 3PM you will be charged 1000 yen per hour even if your room is free and already ready, to watch satellite TV to get other channels than japanese channels you must buy a 1000 yen TV card and to borrow a converter from the reception to charge my computer I had to go back to my room and bring a 1000 yen bank note as a deposite... Excellent location, very central but very disappointed by this hotel and the quality of service

We stayed at this hotel last year in a twin room which was tight but sufficed for 2 nights;this time we made the mistake of booking a double & we struggled to fit into this tiny space. I know rooms in Japan can be small but with 2 suitcases,one of which was cabin sized, the room felt very overcrowded.Having said that, it is a good location with Tokyo station about a 15 minute walk away,the fish market about 20 mins,subways close by and the main shopping of Ginza at the top of the street. There are quite a few department stores on the Main Street and many of these have good restaurant options on their upper floors. There are a couple of small supermarkets across the road for drinks and snacks.

This hotels most attractive quality is definitely it's convenient location. We arrived from Haneda airport and took the Keikyu airport line straight to Higashi Ginza station. We exited the station at exit A8 and the hotel was literally a small block and a half away. The trip took roughly 25 min. The hotel is located very close to many other subway stations as well. The Ginza-Itchome station (Y19) is a block away, the Ginza station is 5 blocks away and the JR Yurakucho station is 7 blocks away. Thus, it gives great access to many subway lines to navigate the sprawling city. The JR Yurakucho station gives easy access to the monorail which has express trains to Haneda airport via Hamamatsucho station. The hotel is a 730 yen taxi ride from Tokyo station. It is also a short walk from the Marriott hotel which the Hatobus company (which offers many sightseeing tours) uses as a possible pick up location.The hotel is located literally 3 small streets away from the heart of Ginza, an area full of upscale restaurants and shops. It is full of day long hustle bustle (on weekends they close the streets to vehicles due the sheer number of pedestrians). Most stores usually open at 11am and close late into the evening. Ginza is famous for its large department stores. For me (the food lover), the most impressive were the basements of these department stores specifically those of the Mitsukoshi Ginza department store (the most popular) but the Matsuya Ginza as well. The sheer offerings and varieties of food vendors in these basements are something to take in!!!There are 2 convenience stores directly outside of this hotel to meet most, if not all of your needs. The Kabuki theatre is 5 blocks away and the Tsukiji fish market is a short walk away.This hotel is clean and rather roomy in my opinion for Tokyo standards. There was also free WiFi. For my stay in Tokyo, I thought it was a great find.

The Monterey Ginza proved a good choice of hotel: very close to central Tokyo, its department stores and unaffordable brand shops, and an easy walk to Ginza station. The room was certainly small, as we had expected, but their fit-out like that of the hotel as a whole was stylish and modern, and housekeeping included provision of new pajamas daily! Given city hotel costs the room rate was very reasonable, and ours included a good varied buffet breakfast. The hotel does lack public areas to sit, though. We found a good range of restaurants near the hotel, despite the one unhelpful check-in clerk (maybe a trainee) who just suggested we heade for the main railway station, put us in a smoking room and generally gave little help on our arrival: the other staff were fine.

I chose this hotel because we were staying in Tokyo a few days after a cruise. This hotel is 3 short blocks off the main Ginza, so it is very quiet,(there is construction accross the street but the noise was not a problem) yet close to all the shopping and subway station. You can walk to Tsukijii Fish Market and Kabuki Theatre. There are lots of places to eat ( check out the first basement floor at the department store) Our room was located on the top floor 1332. We were lucky because I think it is a little bigger, the bathroom was a nice size not like the other 2 hotels we stayed in Japan. We had 2 twin beds which makes it feel like there is more space, and even 2 closet space!! The room was very clean and the refrig was nice to have. The pillow was a problem for me.

Hotel Monterey a classy boutique hotel, just off the main shopping strip in Ginza. It is quiet (see photo). It's a short walk, or short cab ride (Y750) from Tokyo Station. It is also a short walk to the Tokyo International Forum Conference Centre, which was the purpose of my visit to Tokyo.Yes, the rooms are half the size of the large hotels, but guess what else is half? The tariff. The rooms have a double bed, a desk, a wardrobe, a plasma TV (see photo) - who wants more when there is the whole of Tokyo to explore? Next block there is a restaurant which serves pork schnitzel. The restaurant is so authentic it does not have an English name - recognize it by the illuminated pig. And then there's Nelson's Bar (see photo).The breakfasts are magnificent - held in a chandelier festooned room, with Western and Japanese buffets. There is an omelet chef who is always busy, mizo soup,, mini croissants and pains de chocolat, fresh fruit, and a double espresso - a great way to start the day (see photos).The breakfast rooms are used for wedding receptions, and plaques of the names of the happy couples are found on the stairwell (see photo).Highly recommended for anyone who wants a quiet corner in the heart of Tokyo.

This otherwise well located hotel has strategically taken photos on their website that do not reveal how small their rooms are! We made the mistake to book it last October and were dismayed to note that we could hardly fit in the room allocated to my wife and I and had to step over luggage to get in the bathroom or out of the room as there was no space to unpack. The tiny cupboard with six hangers was certainly unable to handle our staff and had we not found a replacement hotel the next day our first time in Tokyo would have been ruined.On the plus side it is cheap clean and usable for one person without great demands. The location is also very good.

This hotel is a few blocks from the Ginza and walking distance to the fish markets. The subway (yellow line) is 50 metres from the hotel so a day pass gives you all of Tokyo's attractions. the hotel has small rooms by international standards but comfortable and well equipped.Would stay there again. There are some very good eating establishments nearby.

If you're looking for a good budget hotel strategically located in Ginza, look no further, this is your place! Location wise, it is hard to find any fault with its being located near the Ginza Chuo Dori and only a few hundreds meters away from the Ginza subway station. There's also a convenience store right across the street of you ever need to buy snacks or such.As for the room, it was clean, had comfortable beds, and while it was nowhere spacious, it was adequate for me, my 2 friends, and our small suitcases. They also provided all the basic amenities such as soap, shampoo, toothbrush, slippers, etc. The best part is, the mini bar was included in our room rate so we could take anything we want from the mini fringe (ranging from veggie juice to chuhai) free of extra charge. For a budget traveler such as my self, it was a pleasant bonus. All in all, I think it will be very hard to find any better place at this price range.

The relative value is high because the hotel is at pretty good location and charge is competitive with peers. Also room is clean, service is good as well. Hotel Monterey Ginza will be one of my top choice for the next time stopping by Tokyo.

Comfortable, clean, quiet, friendly and extremely conveniently located. Very highly recommended, and I will definitely stay here again.Liked: Everything about this charming hotel.Did not like: Nothing to report

With an efficient check in, well appointed rooms and excellent location the Hotel Monterey Ginza is a great choice for a stay in Tokyo. Ample great food and beverage options nearby and one block access to transport, this hotel will exceed most visitors' expectations.

As any typical Tokyo hotel, the room is small and the amenities are basic. But what makes up for it is the location. As you step out of the hotel, a block away is the entrance to one of the stations in Ginza. A few more blocks and it's the main shopping street. Walk a bit further and its the restaurants and bars. Everything within walking distance. Good for a city like Tokyo where taxis are expensive....

The best thing about the Monterey Ginza is its location in the middle of Ginza. While I usually love the hotels from the Monterey chain, this one was a bit of a disappointment. Our room was small and the strange dark wooden floor made it seem even smaller. It was hard to find space for a small and medium sized suitcase. Noise from other guests was an issue. The reception area was constantly crowded with people. Staff was not exactly welcoming and helpful. However, the location is good, the room was clean and everything worked ok.

Our Tokyo Ginza hotel room where we stayed for three days seemed like a shoe box. Very compact with just enough room to get dressed and make your way to the bathroom, and out. It is compact living at its best, and yet everything is in its place and very orderly and clean. It is located an easy walk from the Ginza, Tokyo's most famous upmarket shopping, where you will find dining, entertainment, numerous department stores, boutiques, and art galleries. Although a restaurant is located in the hotel, for breakfast we chose to walk to the Doutor and Starbucks coffee shops located nearby. There is also a friendly convenient store across the street. The hotel is short taxi ride from the Tokyo Station.

We had to get 2 rooms for a family of 4. At first they could not give us connecting rooms but rooms on the same floor only. However a few days before, when we asked if they can confirm the rooms will be on the same floor, they said connecting rooms are available. We also got 2 twin beds in each room versus 1 double bed. No extra charge.We landed in Narita and took the Narita Express. The lady there gave us the wrong tickets, so the conductor asked for $19 additional for each passenger. There is a Tokyo Direct Ticket that will cost you $15 only for this leg only. Does not work when going to Narita. We ended up paying $30 for each.....argh. And trying to explain the issue to the conductor when we cannot speak Japanese was getting us nowhere. We turned on our roaming to get service to show him the website but no connection. So be wise and take a photo of the promo. Or make sure you have the right ticket.We got off the Tokyo station. It was a bit of a walk to Yaesu South exit. Look at the map. You won't see signs for the Yaesu South exit but the map will show you to follow the central signs, which will then connect to where you want to go. Eventually, you will see signs for the Yaesu South exit. Look for the Taxi sign. Go outside and get in line. We had to take 2 taxis as we had two 28 inches and three 22 inches. I asked the first taxi to let the second taxi know. I can't speak Japanese but with gestures, the driver understood. The first taxi was 820 yen. Second taxi was 730 yen. It took but 5 min? to get to the hotel.The front desk was very friendly and helpful. We have asked for places to eat, directions, etc.They reserved a taxi for us to go back to Tokyo station. We got a van taxi, so we all can fit. Cost us 2500 yen. We also asked to extend the checkout of one of the 2 rooms. We payed 1000 yen per hour of extension.Now we have connecting rooms. And unlike in US, you need a key to lock the doors between the rooms. Not knowing Japanese, we struggled to explain that we needed the door locked since we are only extending the 1 room. Did not want the new guests on the other room to have access. In the end, I asked the cleaning lady and showed her the unlocked door. And with that and gestures, she understood and called the front desk. Voila, mission accomplished, someone came up and locked the door.The rooms have shampoo, conditioner, body liquid soap, hand and face liquid soap. They also provide, shavers, toothbrush, comb, hair clip, cotton buds, slippers to keep. They also have pajamas but those you cannot keep.They have a small fridge that has beverages for purchase. A hot water machine if you want yo make coffee. We did not use the humidifier. TV is small and no English channels but that was okay. We saw icarly dubbed in Japanese and that was interesting. My kids love anime so they were happy to watch then in Japanese.The air conditioning was good and the shower was strong. The room has enough lighting and was bright. It has a thick curtain to keep light out. If I have to nitpick, they don't have body lotion. Also, the towels smells like fish or tempura. Not sure why.There is a family mart across the street. There is also a Sunkus, which is another convenience store. Across the Sunkus, is a ramen place and it is good. Tonkatsu Tonmi, which was recommended by Fodor's is also nearby. Look for the yellow pig sign on the doorway. It was really good and cheap. Unfortunately, the tempura only came with 2 pieces. I wanted 10 more. We walked to Mitsukoshi everyday and took the subway there. The food hall has Johan Bakery and we bought some bread for breakfast.

We enjoyed the service the location and the hotel's hospitality . The room was small but clean. The breckfast was good including Japanese food and western food. The location of the hotel is very good walking distance from the fish market and ginza shopping area

This is my first time to Japan and I couldn't be happier with the hotel. The convenience store is directly across the road and the train station and McDonalds are a 1 minute walk away. The front staff have been very helpful and considerate, even helping me work out the most economical way for me to buy train tickets based on our daily plans. Yes, the room is quite small, but it's immaculately clean and contains everything I could need. Free, fast internet without having to worry about a password was also nice. It's the first place I've ever stayed that has full-sized pump bottles of shampoo, conditioner and body wash, rather than those tiny one-use bottles. I would definitely stay here again.

Good value hotel. Small rooms, a little dated but comfortable and clean. Quiet Ginza neighbourhood. Plenty of coffee, mini marts and shops in surrounding streets. Close to main street shops. Easy walk to the underground trains. Would stay again.

Perfect place to stay for a couple of days in Tokyo prior to returning home after a cruise out of Yokohama. Friendly and helpful staff and a clean and sizable room, with free WiFi (worked well). Very comfortable bed and quiet location. The buffet breakfast offered a wide range of tasty and well presented Asian and western food. A short walk (about 1.2 km) from Tokyo station and in a very safe business and up-market area. Would thoroughly recommend.

This hotel was slightly run down and the rooms were extremely small. I've traveled to Tokyo before and know that the city hotel rooms tend to be small but this hotel was like staying in a closet. The room was clean but the AC worked only about 50% of the time. The hotel front desk staff were useless. The first night we checked in at 1am and asked the front desk staff if any restaurants in the area were open. The front desk said only the family mart was open across the street; however, when we walked outside there were two bars/restaurants open directly next to the family mart! They also refused to help my husband and I call a restaurant to make a reservation for dinner - we don't speak Japanese fluently. The hotel was in a wonderful location in Ginza. About two blocks off the main strip so nice and quiet yet close by and within walking distance to all the restaurants and shopping that are the reasons to stay in Ginza. If you only need a place to rest your head at night I guess this hotel would suit your needs.

Excellent experience overall . The room and bath room size is decent by Tokyo Standard . However , the quality of material used in the room as well as the amenities hotel provided makes us feel very conformable, almost home like .This feeling just gets more distinct when you start to compare with other Tokyo hotels . One thing to remember , do take the nearest metro station (Ginza Itchome ) on the Yurakucho Line instead of walking to Marunouchi Line . That's the distance you don't wanna walk after a long day in Tokyo . The other advantage of Its location is when travelling to Tokyo Disney resort . You only need to change once onto the Keiyo line with very minimum walking distance and total travelling time is less than 30 mins .I have nothing more to ask for . I love this hotel !

great location in the heart of Ginza , close to Tokyo station , however being in the heart of Tokyo rooms were rather small but still doable . just opposite a convenience store . close to a shopping center and lots of shops and restaurants

We were surprised with the size of the room. We thought it would be smaller. Overall service was great and the breakfast terrific. We found the position was very central to get a great overview of Toyko. Pub across the road great atmosphere for a quiet drink. Locals very helpful to newbie travellers.

We originally booked a non-smoking room as I cannot stand the smell however, they assigned us the smoking room. We got to the room, it was awful. Room was so small, smelt like someone just smoked and came out of the room and the room looked really dated and tired. I did call the reception to change the room, they were more than happy to accommodate my request which was lovely. Next time, I would only book the newly renovated side of the hotel. Its more expensive but its worth it. Don't stay here if you want to save money and stay in the old part of the hotel. Location was amazing. In the middle of the Ginza. Very close to a lot of train stations and also close to terminal bus stations that takes you to either Narita or Haneda. It cost us around $30 USD to get to Ginza from Narita airport one way.

3 nights at this hotel and I like the location, room as it is located a few blocks away from the core Ginza areas, 15 minutes away from Tsukiji, where I had lunch on a Saturday afternoon. I have had dinners at nearby restaurants, take-outs from basement of Matsuya department store a few blocks away (Mitsukoshi department store is also nearby). No complaints on eating. And the nearest subway station is only 1-minute away. Of course the major JR station is about 10-minute away if you will be coming to/from Tokyo station and/or airport by JR.I'll definitely consider to stay at this hotel once again if I'll be in town again next time.

It is a good property if you need to stay in the center of the city & access Ginza or shenjuku. I only got a chance to stay for 1 night but what i liked was the location. The service is normal. The breakfast table is elaborate

Stayed in this hotel for a night only for business purpose (attending an expo), conveniently located in the heart of Ginza, easy to get some food and do some shopping. Most importantly is it's HOMEY :)

walking distance to major Tokyo attractions. close to fish market ,lots of small restaurant and food are real cheap. the front desk staff wasn't very friendly. the room was okay for the price we paid. the location was good, if you call taxi it cost you 1400 to JR Tokyo station.

Back in the day, everything in Tokyo was wildly expensive for someone coming from the U.S. So it was a pleasant surprise to find a nice hotel like the Monterey Ginza for such a reasonable price. OK it's not the Four Seasons, but it's still quite pleasant. Decent sized rooms by Tokyo standards. Clean, quiet, and nice pajamas. Some other reviewers have complained about indifferent staff, but the person who helped me was very helpful. There are two things to be aware of, however. First, the check-in time of 3 p.m. is a bit on the late side, and their policy is to charge 1000 yen per hour for early check-in. Second, not all the rooms have wi-fi, I had to use the cable (provided) in mine. (Not an issue for most people, but if you have a computer without an ethernet jack, such as a Macbook Air, be sure to bring your ethernet dongle.) The internet service was a bit spotty, usually OK but it would slow down from time to time.

Excellent location in the heart of Ginza. Walking distance to 6-8 of the major Tokyo attractions.The front desk staff was absolutely superb and really made a difference in the overall experience. The property itself is a bit more dated than the website photo's, but in good shape. The room was average size for Tokyo and everything worked perfectly. Easy, reasonable ( less than 1000 yen / 10 USD) taxi ride from Tokyo Station, after taking the Narita Express in from the airport.(Note: inbound NEx is 1/2 price for foreign passports holders.) Not exaggerating when I say there are 100+ restaurants within a 8-10 block radius, many times a restaurant or two on each floor of a multi-story building. Also, 2 convenience stores across the street and 4-6 coffee houses within 2 blocks. ( and the mandatory McDonalds less than 2 blocks). We would return to this hotel during a future Tokyo trip.

we stayed one night at this hotel. Having stayed at the Monterey Kyoto for 5 nights, this hotel was disappointing. The rooms v v small. Bathrooms were fine. However the general tone of the hotel left much to be desired. The staff were not particularly helpful. The location of the hotel was good. I would not recommend this hotel for any more that one night. It is a short taxi ride to Tokyo station. It is a few mins walk to down town Ginza. Many shops restaurants close by.

The Hotel Monterey chain in Japan has an European feel. This Ginza property has old drawings of French characters & scenes framed & hung along the corridors of the floors. There is a chapel mostly for weddings (Japanese like to host weddings in Western suits, gowns and settings as well as in traditional garb). But the chapel here is smaller than the Monterey in Osaka. Some days the room is used as restaurant open to the public, somedays, it is for wedding reception, somedays it is not used at all. Hotel lobby could do with more chairs (because there is a long line of people waiting), but there isnt enough space. Rooms are clean; beds are somewhat hard, but pillows are comfortable. View from window does not offer much other than another building. Breakfast is served on 2nd level -- diners tend to be very quiet because the restaurant has an air of elegance. Hotel location is near Mercure chain in case you get lost in the neighborhood. Near the hotel are plenty of cafes, including affordable take-away (Le Café Doutor Ginza).

We loved our visit to Tokyo and stayed in this hotel for 4 nights. It was difficult to find the hotel first but then we were able to navigate the city better and enjoyed our stay in this little hotel. I loved the pajama service :) me and my fiancé had matching pajamas that were placed on our bed :) The room was small but the location of the hotel was great in Ginza and it was in a great neighborhood.

so handy to all transport, shops and restaurants! the location is good but the instructions from your webpage is not accurate and we ended up circulating the side streets before we found the hotel. it was raining heavily and that we did not like!

The reviews here are accurate- the Monterey is really well situated for the visitor to Tokyo and is very good value.The bed is comfortable, room service good, wi-fi excellent, quirky features such as the toilet electrics (fun and practical) and comfy cotton pyjamas provided every night made this a positive experience. The overall hotel facilities are limited but Ginza is on your doorstep and for good food go around the corner to Cafe Pour- fresh, flavoursome food in a cafe-restaurant which could be in Paris or Rome.As well as the metro next door the hotel is 10-15 minute walk from the main Tokyo train and bus stations ( called Tokyo- a clue! Remember Tokyo has 12 million people so it would be a bit like a train station called London or New York). This is where the airport trains come in to and where the shankensen ( bullet trains) leave from.Rooms are small but practical, TV instructions unclear, hair-dryer,tea and coffee provided in room along with mini-bar. Reception can provide electricity adaptors and irons at no charge. bathroom has shaving/sewing/toothpaste kits in abundance. Reception staff like all Japanese; courteous and take a pride in their work- will store luggage and sell metro travel passes cheaper than stations

Fantastic location opposite a metro and a walk to the Palace. We upgraded on arrival which was good value - a small amount of cash got us a much bigger room. The room was bright but could do with a repaint and was a bit bashed around the edges. Super fast wifi. Typically amazing Japanese loo and the free pyjamas were very comfy. Staff at the front desk friendly and it was close to a very useful mini market and a great French bakery.

Good locationToo few staff with little English communicationSome staff is not helpful despite better EnglishCuty with modern French style and decorationNice room decorationOverall service is acceptable

Best hotel in Tokyo. It's near to everything. If you want to eat good ramen its just one block away. If you want to go shopping its just few blocks away. If you want to take the subway train it's just next to the hotel. The hotel personnel were so helpful. I would definitely come back again.

Too many things were not right about this hotel. There are others of similar price or cheaper that do things better. Check in was awful, with a receptionist who demanded passports but didn't coypu them, so the exercise had to be repeated later that day. Windows can only be opened by the manager and the air con can't be set individually - a rubbish combination. The power sockets are so badly designed that a plug adapter doesn't fit, so an extension cord is needed. On the upside, it's quiet and clean, but so are hotels half this price in Japan.

I chose this hotel for its location.. in the happening district of Ginza and just 6 minutes away from the Tokyo International Forum, which was the venue for a World Ophth Conference. I was pleasantly surprised that the room was of a reasonable size ( japan is notorious for tiny hotel rooms!) with all amenities including a nightly change of nightwear in 2 sizes!The breakfast is quite varied, though the breakfast room tends to fill up fast! They are quite liberal in handing out free umbrellas in case of rain, which you return on coming back to the hotel. The front desk staff is quite helpful and speaks decent English

The Monterey is in a classic style building or classic at least by Japan standards. Location is great in the heart of the Ginza shopping and entertainment district and a short walk to the Shimbashi business district. Also very close to train lines.If you are coming in from Narita there is an express bus that drops you have very close to the hotel and it's no slower than train but substantially cheaper.The room is small and basic, but clean comfortable and functional.

It felt like an old French hotel when you step inside. But the similarity ends there. The room is totally modern and not at all cramped. Wifi in the room. Heated bidet. Fresh pajamas everyday. And the location is perfect. If you must have your morning coffee, there is a Doutor and a Cafe Veloce not 2-minutes away. The Ginza-Itchome stop of the Yurakucho line is next door. Lots of shops and restaurants all around. Over-all a good stay.

The hotel is nicely refurbished and the rooms and toilets are modern and well equipped. Wifi is also available for free in the room. It is a nice comfortable walk to Tsukiji market and there is convenience stores just right downstairs where they have espresso coffee for a very reasonable price. There are also a few ramen restaurants round the corner and izakaya as well. From the hotel, I walked down Ginza all the way to Shimbashi for my favourite Izakaya dinner.However, it is a far walk to the Ginza line. The nearest metro station doesn't really bring me anywhere except Tokyo station. The most inconvenient part is that the hotel is not served by airport limousine. I walked to Marriott Courtyard with my luggage to take the airport limousine. The other options all involve taking either a taxi to the TCAT or changing trains, not desirable with luggage and the crowd.

My wife and I thoroughly enjoyed our stay. No issues or complaints at all. The staff was exceptionally accommodating. In particular your assistance in holding our luggage both before and after our check in/out.

Location is very good . Good value for the money . Very clean place . Rooms rather small . The staff are really helpfull at any time . I did not try the food here so I can not give any comment on this . But I will come back here

Although small and expensive, (but hey, it's tokyo) the rooms are really practical, clean and they spent extra efforts in the small details, which I like!Service is as I am used to in Japan: excellent!Great location too of course!would definitely recommend this one. There's always Okura Hotel, which is so far one of my top favourites, but that comes with a price of course...

The staff at Monterey Hotel Ginza are very good. The room is always neat and clean. It would be nice if an English newspaper would be placed on the door each day as it seems that Japanese newspapers are place on the doors of Japanese guests. The front desk staff did give me a newspaper when I requested it, which was nice.

Given the fantastic location in the middle of the Ginza and the super-reasonable room rate, we were expecting that the room itself might be sub par. How wrong we were. Our room was modern, spotless and, by Japan standards, LARGE. Our bathroom was correspondingly roomy. The heated toilet seat was to die for. The wi-fi signal in our room was good enough for streaming videos. We had subway stations on our doorstep. Tsukiji fish market is just a pleasant stroll away, as is Yurakucho. We were pleasantly surprised by this hotel, and would gladly return here.

Yes, the rooms, especially the one we got, are really small. But this is the only minus.Location is topnotch. On one side you have the glitz and glamour of Ginza, and on the other the quaint little shops and restaurants on east Ginza. All the conveniences abound within a few steps from the hotel's doorstep: 24-hour store, shoe repair, pharmacy, all sorts of restaurants and all the kinds of coffee shops one can possibly imagine.The room has all the amenities including pyjamas in the softest cotton, green tea room deodorizer spray, and all the other usual stuff but in my view quite tastefully rendered. The hotel seems owned or managed by some quirky French dandy and this shows in the whimsy decor and feel. The service is swift should you need something brought up or changed or replaced. Certainly much better than the other far-more-expensive Tokyo hotel we have stayed in.This is my residence in Tokyo going forward.

Staff very patiente and helpfullLocation greatEasy to access metroRoom is clean and not so small as i read .....bettrr do not book hotela in Milan or Paris....I will recommend this hotel to any of my contactsGinza line makea easy to move to any direction.easy to go to street market..ASAKUSA ...from ginza stop

Last week, i stayed at Hotel Monterey Ginza and was very disappointed of the room type I booked online didn't much what I selected and when I asked the front desk staff, she claimed it was correct. Honestly, I have been staying with Hotel Monterey Japan from Fukuoka, Osaka and In Tokyo, I often stayed at Hotel Monterey Ginza La Soeur Ginza and thought I gave a try at next block. However, I found the front desk staff were a big disappointment as they were not helpful, lack of TCAT limo bus schedule knowledge and at time, they pretended not to attend to our questions. I was not the only guest who feel it because I booked 3 rooms and 2 of my friends who stay at La Soeur felt the same. We still like Hotel Monterey but will go back to La Soeur instead on Ginza because the staff there are friendly and knowledge. I hope this feedback help Ginza staff to change their attitude. Best, Andy

Ginza is probably one of the most expensive place for any retailer but that does not have to be when it comes to hotel. Very much affordable for someone who is on a budget but requires a central location in Tokyo. Hotel is not that big but it's comfortable. The hotel is walking distance (about 10 mins) to Tokyo station. Tokyo station is one of the central places to take the train if you plan to visit outside of Tokyo. The hotel is just around the corner from shopping centres with plenty of food choices and shopping, if that's your thing. I stumbled upon this hotel when i was searching for hotels in Shinjuku as that is where i usually go to. But since the hotels there were fully taken and the ones left costs as much as my plane ticket, i decided to go with Hotel Monterey. Would definitely check them out again if i am heading to Tokyo.

We love Ginza in Tokyo. It is much quieter than other major areas. This Hotel is convenient to Tokyo Station..you can walk there from the station. There are 2 convenience stores right there for you to pick up essentials. It is handy for moving around Tokyo. The rooms are clean, and staff are friendly.

Hotel is in a very good location. close to major shopping area and access to trains.The customer service is very poor. When checking in they want you to furnish the reservation details. I gave them my name and told the front desk that the reservation was made online. Instead the girl directs me to a computer in the front lobby to retrieve my reservation from my email and i had to pay 100 yen to access the computer. Also we were stuck in tokyo during the recent snow storm and had to return back to the hotel for an extra night. we came back about noon and was told that check in time was 3 pm and that for every hour early that i checked in , i would have to pay 1000 yen extra. After some heated discussion with the front desk they allowed us to checkin at about 1pm without further fees. I would not stay here again just based on the poor service of the front desk.

My husband and I stayed 3 nights in this miserable room. I assumed too much , I guess, but this room had a double bed which was accessible from only one side and the foot. I had to climb over my husband to get in and out. While sleeping I had my nose up against the wall. There was absolutely no shelving, drawers, or ledges to store clothing so I lived out of my suitcase which I set on the one chair, piling unnecessary stuff on the floor underneath. Hotel itself is fine old building . Lovely staff and service, fine breakfast, great location. Bathroom is quite roomy . All is clean. Temperature in room is too hot and couldn't be adjusted

We are a family of 4, with kids age 11 and 14 and have recently stayed at Monterey Ginza in 2 occassions, each time booking 2 rooms each that we requested to be next door to each other or at best close by. We were more than happy with the size of the room, taking in consideration that it will be compact. In saying that, we have stayed at other hotels in Japan that was much much smaller! The cleaning staff is to be commended for the great job they do. We requested non-smoking room/floor and not a whiff of smoke was smelt. Wifi was available in the rooms so a hit with the kids, as they can vege out and use their mobile devices after the day's outing. Our 1st day was for 4 nights, at the start of our trip and we were happy with the hotel that we booked another 2 nights for the last leg. We opted out of breakfast, but plenty of options available across the road. There are 2 convenience stores which are open 24 hours, kids were happy to have croissant/pastry with a hot chocolate or there's a Dotour cafe (franchise) opposite that do a coffee/hot cocoa and toasted sandwich for 380 Y before 10:30am. Location was great as well, lots of eateries close by, check them out in nearby streets, lots of choices. Easy access to Tokyo Station to catch that Shinkansen or from Narita Airport. Staff were helpful in assisting us with forwarding luggages and/or storing them. Highly recommend.

When we arrive on July 18-22 of 2013 I was very scared as I heard people smoke in hotels in Tokyo and I have asthma. Well my worse fear came true, In our first night in Tokyo my room and none smoking room had smoke came all over the room from people down the hall. I had to sleep with a mask and cover my face dying from my asthma, so I couldn't sleep. The next day I went to the front desk and ask them to move me to a room far away from smokers, because no matter how far the smoke come thru the vents. The staff was very nice they move all our luggage for us so that we didn't lose any time of our travels. When we came back to the hotel they had moved every single thing and my new room was smoke free, not even any smell thru the vents, all clean air and even a bigger room. The rooms are small but this room was big for Tokyo standards. I really love the location was quite but had everything. We had the train station in front, also stores, restaurants. everything very convenient and clean. I wish the staff spoke more English but Japanese people are so nice that you don't even need to know the language. Fantastic trip!!!! we just wish they didn't smoke. lol

We've stayed at the Monterey on 3 occasions so they must do something right. The Monterey is good value for money and it is a reasonably priced hotel. Booking directly through the hotel's website is relatively easy.The rooms are comfortable but typical Japan small. A double for a couple should be more than adequate but if you're like us and travelling with a toddler and travel cot/crib we had to book a twin because it is slightly larger than a double and you can't book a double with a child. Even so there's not much floor space left once the cot is up. Apparently cots/cribs are available from the hotel for infants but when the child is older than one the child is expected to sleep in the parent's bed or you bring your own cot. The beds are comfortable and the bathroom facilities are fine. Typical of most Japanese hotels they have had free wired internet in every room and now they have free WiFi in the rooms which is fast and easily connectible. There's the usual TV and minibar in the room.In Winter the air con is too warm and the room gets a little stuffy. Housekeeping can open the windows but the open window is extremely dangerous with kids.I should mention the cute complementary pyjamas. A nice touch but a bit tight for a big fella like me. :)The Monterey is conveniently located near Metro stations, restaurants and shopping. The heart of Ginza is only 5 minutes walk away. The neighbourhood, considering it has so many restaurants, is very quiet. It is a great part of Tokyo and is very convenient to the Tsukiji Fish Market.The service from the hotel staff ranges from extremely helpful to quite abrupt when they won't or can't do something for you. For example the famous Sukiyabashi Jiro restaurant requires reservations from foreigners be made by the hotel they are staying at. Jiro refuses all reservations from the Monterey. We wondered why the hotel staff refused to even attempt to try and make a booking and they offered no explanation. After asking at Jiro we were told that Jiro blames the hotel for not doing the right thing when a guest or guests were a no show at the restaurant. For the record you need to give Jiro about a months notice to make a reservation anyway. If you really want to go to Jiro stay at another hotel. Otherwise it is a good hotel in a good location for a reasonable price. We'll probably try somewhere else next time though.

I stayed here the first time I went to Japan and the staff was just great. I love the lobby and the rooms were nice and clean.It is the perfection location in Ginza with nice shopping, awesome restaurants, and bars close by. This is one of my favorite hotels in Tokyo.

Room quite big for Tokyo, TV, Minibar... Bathroom ok. Noisy nights because of the air condition.We had cheaper hotels in Tokyo which where better. In the center of Ginza, 50 meters to the next metro station.

location was great as it was near tsukiji fish market and high-end shopping areas. downside was the room size and was given a smoker's room (smell was bad), tried changing it but they weren't very helpful. it was a tad bit run down as well.

Hotel location was perfect and close to everything. Rooms were a bit small but very clean. Staff were so friendly and knowledgable. Service was great. We had to pay for breakfast but it was so worth it! They had both Western and Japanese cuiseine. Nothing bad to say. Will definetly stay here again.

This hotel is on a quiet street a couple of blocks off the main Ginza shopping street. You can get a very good rate by booking and paying well in advance on one of the online booking sites. The place has an impressive Art Deco lobby, but the rooms are pretty ordinary. Small (after all, this is Tokyo!), plainly decorated, but very clean. Bed was comfortable and the room was very quiet. My biggest issue with the room was the ventilation system. This is an old building, so once the heat in the building goes on, there's no way to reduce the temperature, not with the thermostat in your room and not by opening a window. This issue was pretty noticeable as we were there on some unseasonably warm fall days. Running the air purifier in the room helped by giving some air flow, but even then, the room was warm and stuffy. Despite that limitation, this is still a decent place to stay if you're looking for a good value in the Ginza area.

We spent 3 nights here. It is an absolutely great location in Ginza, one of the top shopping districts in the world. As pointed out by other reviewers, the rooms are small, but very clean. As recommended by other reviewers, we requested the 13th floor. Other reviewers complained about the quality of wi-fi, but we found it excellent. I would definitely recommend this hotel.

We spent three nice in this perfectly located Hotel in Ginza. The staff was very nice and attentive to our needs. Be hold, the room are rather small but very convenient. The mattress was harder than the floor but amazingly I slept as a baby. Nothing to say about the cleanliness of the room. This hotel has a very good good quality/price ration.

My wife and I stayed 6 nights in this hotel in early November. The hotel was a great find especially considering the price we paid ($110 Canadian per night). The hotel is close to everything - Ginza shopping is just 3 short blocks away. Tokyo Station is within 1 km. We managed to walk from Tokyo Station to the hotel on our arrival with luggage. On the way back (burdened by all the spoils of shopping) we took a cab and it cost as ~700 Yen. The hotel is on a quiet side street so there was no noise issues. Staff was very helpful. They helped us make a few reservations for various events around Tokyo. Their English is good and if they have problems communicating they have a lot of written material prepared for your convenience - maps, subway tickets, event brochures, etc.The room we stayed in looked recently renovated. It was small, but clean with a very nice bathroom (deep tub with a shower). The furniture is basic, but functional. But please remember, this is Japan, not North America so rooms are small. There is no safe in the room, but the hotel has a safe at the reception. Japan is very safe anyway...The only complaint I have about the room is the bed - hard as a rock with hard as a rock pillows. Hotel has an overall French theme (there seems to be some sort of French cultural invasion happening in Japan with all the french bistros, restaurants and cafes). Wedding receptions seem to be happening on the regular basis. The hotel is surrounded by number of restaurants, so finding a meal (especially a breakfast) is not a problem.

Stayed here for five nights for attending conference. The internet connection is decent, except the wifi reception is a little bit difficult in the hotel's public area (such as the breakfast place 2nd floor, and receptionist). Perhaps, they want to limit non-guest to use their internet. Anyway, inside the room, signal is strong.I stayed at the 13th floor. At one night, a colleague who stayed on 4th floor came to my room, and he said that it was better than his room (more spacious). I didn't go to check how is his room, but it can be a tips for you who plan to stay in this hotel. Ask for 13 floor !!Hotel is centrally located in Ginza. Many shops, restaurants, shopping centers, and attractions. Two metro stations are in very close proximity from the hotel. Since it's Ginza, the street will still have people walking on it, even at 12 AM. So, if you enjoy Tokyo so much, don't be afraid to go home late to the hotel.The hotel also sells 1-day and 2-day ticket for unlimited metro use. You can get them at the receptionist for special price (usually only sold at airport). The 1-day ticket is JPY 600.I found some good places to eat around this hotel (check the photo section of my review for the restaurant name). Sushi is around JPY 1600, tempura is around JPY 680. IMO, the tempura taste is better than the ones in Asakusa (so which one is the authentic one?).

My husband and I loved this hotel. Its in the heart of Ginza so great location! and there were 2 metro station extremely close to this location.price was great, the washroom was clean. decent size room.

We stayed in this hotel 2x (Oct 30-Nov 1 & Nov 2-4) in one trip to Japan breaking midway to spend the weekend overnight out of town.Like most Japanese hotels, it has small rooms but very clean (On our 1st leg they put us on the 13th fl w/c has newer rooms that are a bit more spacious! On our 2nd leg they put us on the 9th fl where rooms were older, tighter, but still very clean) Not too good service though, no one helped w/ our luggage, front desk not always helpful with directions nor with just calling a cab!?! Even at breakfast, the staff kept on reminding us (to hurry us up!) that it ends at 10! (Always had a wedding reception after) LOCATION though is what saved them, 3 min walk fr main st of Ginza where Mitsukoshi, Wako, Uniqlo, Zara, H&M are (abt 5-10min walk); Family Mart & Sunkus convenience stores across the st, an Ippudo (ramen) & Yabaton (miso katsu resto) down the st. All in all we would still want to stay here again!

Being my first time in Tokyo, I was expecting a closet as a room. Was pleasantly surprised, as the rooms are comparable to North American room sizes - I don't know if I lucked out or this room is standard. There is a double bed that could easily fit 2 adults, with a foyer area for luggage. Buffet breakfast is quite expensive and not very good, I don't recommend eating here - there is a cafe very closeby with coffee and pastries. Wifi is terrible, signal is in and out so hard wiring computer is a must to get any consistent connection, LAN cable is provided in the desk drawer. Water bottle from the mini fridge is only a dollar (100 yen) so they are not trying to rip you off. Overall, great place. Would recommend to visitors of Tokyo.

It takes just one underground trip (no line transfers) to get you 400m away from the hotel. This is convenient because a taxi costs 7,700 yen to get here (we tried it both ways.) The room is clean, like all the Montereys, and they provide you with pyjamas (so you can cut down on washing!)

Stayed at this hotel for 5 nights. The location is just amazingly good. It took us just 4-5 minutes by a metered taxi from Tokyo station to the hotel and cost 710 Yen. You can book all your Sightseeing tours by gray line tours and board the bus from Mercure Hotel which is adjacent to this hotel practically a 1 minute walk. You also have a convenio store family mart opposite the hotel to pick up eats or drinks or any thing for the room. All around the hotel within 2-5 minutes walk you can find plenty of stores and restaurants etc. Within 5-7 minutes walk you can reach the most amazing Ginza -Itchome street with all the up market shopping you can find as well as on the parallel road running where on your right you will find the Tokyo station and the Yeasu Hotel for Limousine bus transfers to the Airport. The Hotel itself was nice with comfortable rooms though just that little bit small but then we are in Tokyo. The room had all the necessary amenities as Tea Coffee maker, Fridge, Electronic WC in toilets with all the extras you would require in toilets. The reception staff were very friendly and extremely helpful.

Nice hotel, the staff are very courteous. Clean as. Downsides are there is no room service and the breakfast at the hotel is an extra 2300 yen?! Its also in a very expensive part of Tokyo so keep that in mind if you are on a budget. The location is good but since the transport system is so efficient in Tokyo I wouldn't have this as a deciding factor.

This was my first time in Japan and first time stayed in hotel Monterey in Ginza . I've stayed with my little boy and my mum, very impressed with the service and kindness of the staffs. Will come back next year to Japan and definitely with stay again with Monterey hotel.

We stayed here twice. Three nights when we arrived In Tokyo at the beginning of our holiday and two nights at the end of our two week holiday before we left. Both rooms were small but that is what i would expect in tokyo.The first room was old and stank of smoke and i would have reviewed the hotel 2 stars. The second room was on a floor that was recently refurbished and fully refurbished and 5 star.So overal a decent hotel, great location and friendly staff. lots of rooms are smoking in Japan as so many people smoke. i would recommend this hotel but make sure you ask for one of the newer rooms or at least get a non smoking room.

Hotel Monterey Ginza is an affordable hotel located in the posh Ginza district in Tokyo. If you are arriving from the United States be aware that hotel rooms in Japan are quite small compared to ones in the United States. I stayed for seven days in a standard single room with one double bed.If you are arriving to Tokyo Station from Narita Airport using the NEX express train, you can take a five minute ride on a taxi to the hotel that costs 780-1000 yen ( $10).There is a Family Mart across from the hotel and a coffee shop two blocks away. The closest subway station Ginza itchome is one block away, but I recommend walking five blocks to the Ginza station where you take the subway to Roppongi, Shibuya, Ueno, Shinjuku, Asakusa, and Akihabara districts.Hotel rooms are air-conditioned and the room temperature is adjustable. The hotel also provides dry cleaning services, but it is expensive ( 570 yens for shirts; 820 yens for trousers).Hotel staff are helpful, but like most Japanese residents they speak minimal English. However, you will be able to communicate with the staff.Although there are numerous local Japanee television channels, the only international channel is BBC News. Also, you need to ask for a steam iron.Hotel checkout time is at 11:00 a.m. However, if you have a late flight out of Tokyo, you can leave your luggage at the front desk at no charge. The hotel staff will also call a taxi at your request, but note that dispatching a Taxi costs an extra 400 yens.Overall, I was pleased with the hotel service and its location. The hotel is a 15 minute walk to Tokyo Station and a 10 minute walk to the Tokyo Convention Center. There is a Starbucks close by, just ask the hotel staff.

I've been to Japan and Tokyo several times now, and I always come back to the Monterey Ginza. I find that it fits all my needs, Its very central to tourist spots and shopping, its got very comfy beds (many beds in Japan are hard I find) and its still very clean and chic, even though its been around for quite some years now. It is also very affordable for the money you pay. I've seen people write that its expensive but if you want a good hotel in the heart of Tokyo you'll have to pay the money for it or travel back.The Metro (Ginza-ichome station) is right next door to the hotel. Yurakucho Station (for JR pass holders) is around a kilometre away walking back towards the main street. There are also 3 convenience stores surrounding it as well. We often went down there for snacks/late night food(they are all 24hr) very convenient.So in conclusion, unless you have super high expectations of a hotel and its amenities, this is a quaint hotel that will make you happy. Enjoy Tokyo!

Stayed here for four nights as we got a great rate (40% off for 2 nights or more). The directions from the JR line were somewhat confusing but we found it ! The room was average, but we booked a twin so this gave us enough room to move around. the floors were wooden but nice. the beds were comfortable. The pillows were different and we had to request a second one each, which was quickly supplied. The staff were helpful.Great location, once you know your way. The local JR line is less than five minutes walk lots of very expensive departments stores nearby. However, eating at night was easy as there were lots of very reasonably priced restaurants just outside the hotel.
