downunder2207
Sydney, New South Wales, Australia

review_body: Visited Tokyo in June this year and stayed in this hotel for a week. Firstly, this hotel is in a great location - right next to top designer boutiques and fantastic (albeit pricey department stores) in Tokyo. Great amenities nearby like the metro, JR overground and MacDonalds as well as great Ramen restaurants, bakeries on your doorstep.Hotel reception is dull, old fashioned and uncomfortable - the main entrance is small and drab - they've converted the old entrance to some sort of wedding venue entrance. Anyway, staff were friendly with limited English but they were able to help when asked about the local area.The rooms itself were small and dull. Had a room facing the back of another office block and so had to keep curtains shut all day and night! The room was clean, with wooden floors, fridge, hairdryer, TV an air con. Speaking of the air con, this was hard to control...I got ill from this as it as piping out air from other rooms (which had smokers) and so I slept with the air con off which was very difficult as it was really hot and humid. My throat got really bad from inhaling the passive smoke from other rooms - so beware!

First issue with this place is that the instructions on their website aren't very clear on how to find the hotel, so I would suggest that you Google Map it and plan out how you're going to get from your arrival destination to the hotel. Once you are there though, you're only a minute or so walk from the main strip in Ginza (only 1 stop from Tokyo) and it's very ritzy and this is where all the big TV screens are at the intersections. The room is the tiniest that we stayed in our whole 3 weeks in Japan and the pillows were awful. Like sleeping on a bag full of cement pebbles and when I asked for different pillows, I was straight up told no. The Hotel Monterey group are amazing at stocking your rooms with everything you need - pj's, toothbrush and toothpaste, shaving razor and gel, combs/brushes, shampoo, conditioner, body wash, earbuds, the list goes on so that was a plus. The TV remotes are all in Kanji and the other hotels provide an English guide on how to use them but not this one. When I called reception to ask how to put English subtitles on and how to use the remote in general, I was told no again. I thought that our non-smoking room still smelt a bit smoky too but not enough to complain.Look, the Hotel Monterey group of hotels are lovely, so the rooms are clean, the bathrooms are gorgeous and they all seem to be fairly well priced if you want something a bit fancier, but I'll be looking for somewhere else to stay in Tokyo when I visit again.

This is a very nice hotel with a good location in the Ginza district. There is a subway station only a few meters away from the hotel entrance and a huge shopping street only a few minutes walk from the hotel. The only negative is that the rooms are small, which makes it hard to find any place to put a suitcase (or even worse - two)... The rooms are very quiet which makes the sleeping quality excellent.

Great location in Ginza, near the subway and for JR pass users (like us), relatively close to the JR Yurakucho line (10 min walk) and the JR Tokyo station (10-15 min walk) -- good for travelers heading onto other parts of Japan by rail or to the airport via the Narita Express. We chose the hotel mainly because we wanted to catch the Tsujiki Fish Market auction and no trains would be running that early in the morning; 10-15 walk to the market worked out perfectly and allowed us to go according to plan. Family Mart and various other stores right outside the hotel, extremely convenient.The rooms are no doubt small, but that appears to be the norm for Japan; rooms were quiet, clean and comfortable, not much else we could ask for. Bathrooms were clean and provided all the basic amenities. No problems with the air-conditioning as mentioned in previous reviews.The only downside to this hotel was the poor service -- while the staff were proficient in English, a good number of them were quite unfriendly and even unhelpful were faced with common tourist FAQs. There was, however, one notable exception, an extremely friendly lady who provided a lot helpful advice on the first day, so I guess it'll really depend on your luck and who you're dealing with.All in all, enjoyed the stay in the hotel and would probably stay here again.
We enjoyed our stay immensely, the location was perfect. Our corner twin room was very comfortable. Looking forward to coming back! Breakfast was lovely with both Western and Japanese choices.Dana L.

The location of Hotel Monterey Ginza is very good. There are a lot of great restaurants of every nationality very close by. The metro is only a short walk away. There were 3 issues that reduced my enjoyment of the hotel. Firstly no room safe , which I find very inconvenient. They have a large security box in the office , which we used. Secondly no storage in the rooms. My husband and I were staying for 3 nights and it would have been nice to be able to unpack. Instead we had to live out of our suitcases , on the floor, as there was not even 1 draw in the place. Finally if you have a queen bed you can only get out of bed on one side , as the other is up against the wall. We asked for a larger room but all the larger rooms have twin beds. So, loved the location but too many inconveniences to book again.

Small rooms however we only used them for sleeping.Aircondition functions well, there was no humidity.Very clean hotel with a nice location close to subway and even more important close to a JR station.Staff speaks english.

We enjoyed our stay at the Monterey Ginza. Perfect location right near the shops, train and metro stations, fish market, parks. Wifi in the rooms also perfect and finally room size was for Japanese standards quite large. Definitely a recommendation.

Very convenient to take direct train to and from Hanada airport. Quite and safe place to stay. Very near to metro station and convenient to go elsewhere in the city. Room with twin beds is big when compared with other hotels in Japan. Very reasonable price.

The standard double room is super small. that is too small to open luggage in room. The towel is smell. It mixed with oil and odor that i don't even want to use the towel. The front desk is not helping wiht directions of elevator when i first check in. After i moved all my luggages, they called to my room and offer an exchnage with bigger size room with addtional 3000 yen per night. I am very disappointed about this hotel in Ginza. I stayed at the one in Kyoto. It was much better than the Ginza one. I booked for 4 nights and turned out i checked out earlier to find aother hotel. I will not recommend any of my friends to stay in this hotel.

On the + side, located in the heart of Ginza at a very interesting rate (Ginza ranks among the highest prices in Tokyo). Metro entrance (Y line) is next door, other lines just 5-10 min walk. Facing a Family mart, a Lawson and a mini-mart. Restaurants all around, like taxis and other conveniences.On the - side, no lobby or perhaps too small to call it lobby (?). After a long day visit, you won't have much place to rest at the hotel as your room size does not allow much for resting (except sleeping!) and no lobby, so just head for a nearby coffee-shop (plenty around).Pleasant bathroom. Helpful staff.

The staff upon check-in was super friendly and best thing is that some of them speak really good english. The hotel is perfectly located in Ginza (metro station right in front of the door) and since Ginza being a really fancy area the price of my stay was more than justified. Rooms are perfectly clean and very silent and curtains make the room really dark.

Location is perfect, close to train stations, shopping and plenty of food.At the current exchange rate(Aus) the price was very good value for 7 nights, I did get a 40% off special I believe tho.Service staff were extremely friendly and helpful, although didn't speak a great deal of English but we more than got by :)Room was normal japanese hotel size, very clean and provided all toiletries( razors, tooth brushes, tooth paste, etc) at no additional cost. I'd seen negative reviews regarding AC, I found it to be perfect always keeping the room ice cold(how I like it).I will definitely be staying again on my next trip!!

Stayed for the third time for three nights. It's just round the corner from the main Ginza area. Able to leave our bags there for 4 days and travel lighter to Okinawa. They arranged taxi for our 4am departure.

Came here for a long weekend in Tokyo at the end of May with a few friends. They had gotten amazing deals at the hotel so I booked the same hotel on much shorter notice (and paid about 180$ a night).The best thing about the hotel is clearly its location - right in the middle of Ginza, barely 5 minutes walking from the Higashi-ginza metro station and very close to Tokyo station as well.Within 5-10 minutes walking distance there are plenty of restaurants, shopping centers and 24 hour convenience stores for basic shopping. Compared to other hotels in Tokyo, Hotel Monterey Ginza is also fairly decent value. As is normal in Japan, cleanliness of the rooms is top notch and you're even provided with comfortable pajamas. One other great plus is the free wifi throughout the hotel.However, the rooms are incredibly tiny. My room had barely enough space between the (twin size) bed and the wall to get to the miniature desk. This was fine for one person who didn't spend much time in the hotel but would have been a lot more challenging for a couple. We also had one somewhat confusing service experience (which may have been due to a mis-communication despite the generally good levels of English). When we asked the hotel to help us make a dinner reservation (for a restaurant that later turned out to be literally next door), they flat out refused to do so (but did offer the use of the phone when I started doing it myself). Otherwise service was fine and the hotel did call us a taxi twice.Depending on the occasion I might stay here again for the great location but probably only if I were travelling on my own.

This hotel is nice and cheap to be right in the center of Ginza.Bedroom was nice. Double Kingsize western bedsBath was large, shower was large and comfortable. Staff wasn't as helpful as in other places in Japan. They did mess calling taxy early in the morning.No midnight-bar and restaurant closing early, but with 3 coonvenince shops in the street it wasn't really a problem.

My husband and I have just come back from a great holiday in Japan. This hotal is in a great location, close to railway, shops and restaurants. The room we had was on the 4th floor with a view to the street below. It was quiet, clean, comfortable, good value for money and my husband was fascinated with the ultra modern toilet with all its push buttons for bidet use & warming seat. The staff were friendly. The only one thing I could suggest is to do your research on things to do and tours available as there was only one tour brochure for Mt Fuji and City Tour. They dont seem to promote other attractions like Disneyland or the Zoo etc.

We stayed at this hotel for two nights post-cruise. We were very satisfied with the price and location.The hotel is located two blocks off the main shopping street in the Ginza area. It is right next to Ginza-Itachome metro station; however, the line that goes through that station will not take you to most of the places you want to go in Tokyo. Head instead to the Ginza metro station, and you will have access to all the major subway lines and stops. In addition, you can easily walk to Tokyo station (15 minutes) for the connection to the airport or other destinations in Japan.There are two mini-marts directly across the street for snacks, wine, beer and coffee. There is a 24 hour McDonalds around the corner past the Sofitel. The front-desk staff speak limited English, but it is enough for most hotel transactions. The room is perfectly adequate, spotlessly clean, and has a minibar/fridge. There is free wifi throughout the hotel including the rooms. The hotel will happily hold your bags for you if your room isn't ready, and on your departure day as well if you are not leaving the city until later in the day.We were very pleased with this hotel, and will stay here again if we come back to Tokyo.

My wife and I stood here for a week. The room is very small but clean and cozy. It has sort of a 1960's retro feel to it. Actually, I think the furniture is still the original 60's furniture. We had to prop our suitcases on a couple of chairs that were in the room. Because I have a bad back, the king bed was to my liking, very firm. My wife thought it was a little too hard. The pillows were also to my liking, thick and firm. Again, a bit too much for my wife. The bathroom has very little shelf space to place your personal items, but we managed ok since we have hanging toiletry travel kits. The hotel provides liquid dispensers in the bath/shower which contain body wash, shampoo and conditioner. It's nothing high-end but gets the job done. The toilet is a robot! It has power butt hot water wash and bidet power feature with heated seat, lol. Be ready for an experience if you've never used one of these.The hotel staff are well, Japanese. That's to say that they are very polite, eager to help overall very nice. They do speak some English, so it helped. Any call to the front desk will have your request at your door before you can say rumplestilskin. The front desk sells 1 and 2 day subway passes for the equivalent of about 6 and 9 U.S. dollars, respectively. They also have a map for money exchange locations, which were just a few blocks away. Across the street you'll find a couple of mini-marts where you can purchase anything from breakfast items, to beer for a very reasonable amount. The cashiers there got to know me on a personal level, haha.Taxis are a little more expensive than Hong Kong, our 1st stop, but still cheaper than say, New York City. The restaurants near the hotel are good and convenient. The Ginza strip is but just 2-3 blocks away where you can do some high end shopping or you can just hop on the Ginza-Itchome (Orange) line to many destinations where you can find many other districts. We do recommend the Shibuya crossing in Shibuya. It's the world’s busiest crosswalk with an estimated 1 million people crossing each day. Also check out the Harajuku area where you can shop for bargains and see all of the Harajuku girls and their cool clothes.

Although the room is small, but the location is excellent and service us good. Also the room is very clean. They prepare everything you may need in the bathroom. I will definately come back and stay at this hotel next time!

Our trip to Japan ended in Tokyo mainly to do some shopping. We chose this hotel for the Ginza location. Unfortunately our stay coincided with Japan's Golden Week vacation period so hotel rooms at reasonable prices were impossible to find. However the Monterey Ginza was priced substantially below what we normally pay in the Ginza area (10K less Yen). And for this trip the price difference was greater.The price is great but the twin room size of 200 square feet is limiting. Prior to this the smallest Tokyo hotel room we occupied was 275 square feet. What a difference! If you have more then 2 pieces of luggage you should ask the hotel to remove the small table and chair.Ok done with the main issues; the great "price" and the bad "room size."The service from the front desk to the maid service was excellent especially since communicating in English is never an issue at this hotel. The location is excellent especially for those who like shopping. Restaurants are in abundance including many in the department stores and office buildings. The bean bag pillow is very hard but I got use to it after the second night and it was a very quiet room. The maids kept our room very clean. However when cleaning they left most of the rooms open so cigarette smells daily entered our room. I don't know if hotel has non smoking floors...ask before booking if this is an issue.Overall we would stay at this hotel again if price difference is similar to this trip.

Very Happy with our stay with Monterey Hotel Ginza.Centrally located with food and shops nearby.Room was on small side compared to western hotels, but was clean. Bedding somewhat harder that what we are used to at home. An embarrasing smell in bathroom left by previous occupant was quickly sorted, but should have been recognised prior to our arrival. Staff were friendly and very willing to help. We would recommend hotel Monterey to others to stay at in Ginza.

Reasonably priced, clean, and a great central location. Near the tokyo central train station and there are also many small, fun restaurants in the area. The ginza area is a bit more upscale, so if you are backpacking, it may not be what you are looking for. However, it is a great jumping off point in central Tokyo.

Hotel Monterey Ginza is just two blocks from Ginza main avenue where you find all luxury stores and also close to an entry of the Ginza Itchome station (even if you need to walk 300 meters under ground to reach the entrance of the tickets machine and access to the platform!!!).The hotel is rather comfortable ; the room and bathroom are clean; prices are competitive.The week point, as in many hotels in Tokyo, is that the space is limited, and worse, almost no space, no drawers to store your personal belongings. When you plan to stay two weeks in Tokyo, you can imagine the problem. The luggages cannot be stored, etc...When reserving, ask for twin rooms (a little more space), and avoid double room (the bed is pushed against a wall...)This apart, the hotel can be a good choice if you don't have too many belongings with you.For the breakfast, shop at the grocery store accross the street to have your coffee and rolls in your room!

The Monterey Ginza is just a 15 minutes walk from Tokya Station and easy to find without help. We jusst looked it up on Google maps and counted the traffic lights :=) Street names in Japan is no idea to try to understand...The hotel is modern, very clean with quick service. Descent pricing on the minibar, room size ok. The toilet is a hightech marvel with functions such as antismell, bide, shower with adjustable water strength and a heated seat!Only complaint is that the bed was to hard for my back. Price of the room was very competative.

This hotel exceeded my expectations. We paid about Y15000 per night for a twin during April which was a busy period. Positives - location (close to ginza and not far off Chuo Dori, big main shopping street; 10 min walk or so to Yuracho (home of muji and loft), 20 min walk to tokyo station), convenience stores across the road, friendly staff, discount metro card (for non-toei lines, - bargain Y1000 for unlimited metro over 2 days - according to the Metro site you can usually only get this at the airport... so I was pleasantly surprised), big room for a twin, large bathroom, neat and tidy and clean, fast lan internet (free), walk distance to Tsukiji, european "french"/"art deco" stylingNegatives - no free breakfast (as we were so accustomed to), no 'eco' plans (common in Japan where the hotel will give you a slight discount to encourage you to reuse sheets etc for short stays)

First when you ask about the location of this hotel, the only answer is prime location, perfect for those who like shopping or window shopping. Need a train ride? just walk you are already at Ginza Itchome. Second value for what you paid, very convenient accommodation, very clean and comfortable. That's what we usually need when staying in a hotel. Hotel staffs are very friendly.

My wife and I enjoyed our stay at the Monterey Ginza. Whilst it was quite a small room hotel it was very clean and handy to everything.Service was excellent. There is plenty of places to eat nearby and a convenience store across the road.Love the toilet.

This is modeled after a french hotel, even serving french food in its restaurant.You get the usually twin bed perks, including the supplied toothbrush, tooth paste, razer, shaving cream, etc. which is standard for all of the hotels I have stayed in Japan. Also, the room is small, as are some of the hotels with 2 twin beds and a small bathoom and a tub being easier to use at times than the shower. This is not a knock at this hotel, - this is consistent with what I experienced, except when I stay in the Prince or Hotel Nikko in Osaka or Tokyo. In fact, I like the location very much and the staff spoke English and consistent with Japanese service, was consistently very inconsistent. I didn't go with the standard breakfast meal plan, but there were Starbucks and other coffee shops very close by. Also, Lawson's and Family Mart and a knock-off 7-11 are across the street. We also ate at restaurants across the street which were very good.I would stay there again, as the subway entrance is vey close by and the main drag in Ginza about 2 blocks awat,

I stayed here for 5 nights from 22-27 feb. This cozy French-style hotel is close to the Ginza itchome (round the corner) & Ginza metro ( about 8 minutes walk) stations, hence very convenient. To get to further places beyond Tokyo, one can also walk to the JR Yurakucho station abt 10 minutes away (there's MUJI & The Loft stores near it) and take the train for a stop to transit at Tokyo station (major hub) and then the Shinkansen. Family mart, Lawson's and Sunkus are just opposite for quick grabs. From Narita airport, take the airport limousine to Tokyo station (3000yen) and then cab to hotel (710yen) and vice versa to get to airport. My only complaint was the lousy, flat pillow :p

This hotel is sited in a great location in the heart of the famous Ginza shopping area of Tokyo. Also convenient for the subway and about 5 mins by taxi to the famed fish market. Rooms are clean, and reasonably sized by Tokyo standards - decor is a bit dated and public areas spartan. The hotel reception staff were friendly and speak good english. We stayed for 5 days and still did not have enough time to see all the shops in Ginza! .

This Hotel was plain, but comfortable, the rooms were quite small even for two people. The staff were friendly and welcoming and it was nice to be spoken to in English even though we were in Japan. They kept our cases for us and were very happy to do so, this was convenient for us as we went on a trip to Kyoto during our stay at the Hotel. There was tea making equipment which is always nice, the place was very clean and the staff were efficient. Bathroom was neat and tidy even though it was small. A slight negative thing about the hotel was that the rooms were extremely hot, and staff had to come and unlock the windows for us, and even though we were high up there was no opening restriction, this was slightly scary.The position of the hotel is excellent, near by is central Ginza and the Tokyo Subway. We didn't eat breakfast or any meals at the Hotel, but food was available and there are loads of places just round the corner to eat.

Great location in a central part of Tokyo and close enough to the station (about a 1km walk), nice enough hotel although rooms are small. Otherwise hotel is clean, wifi included (but no breakfast). There's a lot to do around the area (shopping, food etc).

the hotel is easy to find, great location close to two subway lines, walking distance to tsukiji fish market and imperial palace and is two blocks from ritzy Ginza shopping area.  we stayed for 4 nights and had a great time. the rooms were clean, smoke free and all toiletries were available in the bathroom for free if you needed them. they also had a small frige and TV. the front desk was efficient, friendly and spoke a little English which I was grateful for since I didn't speak any Japanese. they were even able to cut my lock off my luggage when I lost the key! and gave good directions to tourist sights. I noticed few westerners in the hotel which was also nice, made it feel like I was in Tokyo instead of in a Hilton full of Americans speaking English. there are two convenient stores across the street and a cheap yummy ramen place 1 block away I'll post a pic if you want to try it.overall, I enjoyed my stay and will stay at this hotel  when I come to visit again. I read some of the other reviews and should mention that the room is on the small side but you're in Japan! We had plenty of room for two people and our big American luggage. I also noticed that they have a pull out couch for another adult or two small children (that they do not advertise on the website). The other complaint I noticed was the 10$ charge for the tv, you can get Japanese channels free but I don't know why you would waste time watching American tv while in Tokyo ......when there is so much to see and experience.Hope this helps and have a great time in Tokyo!!

I paid 220 a night to go back to college. The king size bed is a queen at best. The bathroom is the smallest I've ever seen and super raunchy looking. I got here and Super Bowl Sunday and naturally thinking I could watch in the room but they make you buy tv cards at $10 each! You would think if you paid 220usd you could get to use the tv right?! Not here at hotel Monterey ginza. The only good thing is the location. Never coming here again.

first i want to start with saying that this hotel is by far one of the best hotels ive ever been in. i have stayed at some fantastic hotels across the world ie sheraton in thailand, club med in sicily and some other fantastic hotels all across the globe. this hotel is not only situated in my favourite part of the world but the suburb/district is not only amazingly beautiful but ever so clean and amazing! this hotel is crafted beautifully and the receptionists are just fantastic. we stayed here for one week and as soon as we went to shinjuku we regretted booking other hotels this one was that fantastic!definitely will return to this hotel!

I stayed in this place for a business trip, found it here and booked through hotels.com. The price is very fair for its location - the metro station Ginza-Ichoume is only 200 meters away. Ther personnel is very helpful and educated. The room is pretty small, very small, but I assume that is the case in Tokio anyway, so don't expect a big room. They have nice pijamas waiting for you. Didn't use the restaurant but looked pretty nice. If the price is under $200 go for it.

お正月の終わりに宿泊した。ホテル横にコンビニが3件あり便利、また居酒屋も2件あり立地は良いと思う。JR東京駅に近いホテルとして探したので、部屋は少し狭かったが満足できた。朝食はビュッフェスタイルで入場に多少待たされたが美味しかった。他の方も書いてる通りサービスは普通ですが空気清浄機が常備してあったのはうれしかった。(喫煙の部屋に泊まった)特にこだわりがなく銀座に用事がある人には良い選択のホテルの一つかと思う。I stayed at the end of New Year holidays.There is it, and, the hotel convenience that there are three convenience stores aside, two bars think that the location is good again.Because I looked for it as the hotel which was near to JR Tokyo Station, some rooms were narrow, but were able to be satisfied.The breakfast was kept waiting for entrance in buffet-style to some extent, but was delicious.The service was common as I wrote other one, but was glad that an air cleaner was had always ready.(I stayed at the room of the smoking)I think whether it is one of the hotels of the choice that there are not feelings in particular, and is good for Ginza for a person with the business.

I stayed at this hotel twice in late October 2012 at the start and end of my trip to Japan and had a very comfortable and hassle-free stay both times. Its location was a key highlight for me, on a quiet side street in Ginza yet just a couple of minutes by cab (or 10 mins walk) from Tokyo station (which meant excellent access to the Narita Express and the JR Shinkansen lines) as well as being very close to a couple of subway stops (tip - while the Ginza Ichitome station is literally next door to the hotel, I recommend walking a little further to the main Ginza subway stop which has many more lines running through it). The rooms and bathrooms are clean (as usual in Japan) but as many people have pointed out, a little on the small side and hence ideal for a solo traveller or a couple travelling light. It is very quiet which is a plus and the bed is very comfortable. Free wifi is also available in the room, which was welcome as I found this often not to be the case in Japan. There are lots of small restaurants and cafes, as well as western chains such as Starbucks for those missing a taste of home nearby. Given its location, I would consider this hotel to be very good value and recommend it for whom location and convenience is top priority when visiting Tokyo.

Had a romantic stay at this hotel. The hotel is maybe 5minutes from the Ginza station by foot, however, if you get off at Ginza Ichoume Station it takes maybe 30s from the exit to reach the hotel. Service was great, rooms were clean and really nice. The bed was really big. They were kind enough to fulfill my special request of getting a toy rabbit for my girlfriend before I signed in. I have stayed in numerous hotels in Tokyo and this one is definitely the best. Highly recommended.

We've stayed in this hotel four or five times and keep coming back because: Location is outstanding and it's a great price for this area. Staff is super nice and really willing to speak English and give recommendations -- we've liked 14/15 places they've suggested to us for meals :) Clean and quiet. Negatives: Rooms are small (as is usual in Japanese cities) -- a room w 2 single beds is better than a room w double bed (careful, in Japan they use different terms for double room). They've been complying w/ government request for power saving after Fukashima, and so aircon has been not-so-cool in summer... and last week in winter it was HOT (we just asked them to open our window, which worked just fine to cool the room :) Breakfast buffet isn't to our taste, but it's not easy to find breakfast in Japan (usually we just go to 24-hr restaurant & have something like oyakodon - chicken & egg on rice - for 500 yen). This last trip was as a family -- and it's not so easy to get connecting rooms here, so if that's important to you, be sure to call the hotel.

Stayed here for 4 nights and the hotel is nice and in a really convenient location.Staff were really helpful and English speaking and the room although pretty small was nice and clean. Location is great and easy access to the main streets of Ginza (which is very nice) and also the main subway and train lines are less than 5 mins walk. On arrival in Tokyo we walked to the hotel from the main Tokyo station - only about 10-15 mins and also to the Fish Market - about 15 mins. Recommend it

Just spent a couple nights at this hotel. First of all, let me say that the location is unbeatable. Right in the center of Ginza shopping district and a couple subway stations away from the fish market! The rooms are clean and tidy but VERY small, even by Japanese standards. But the amenities you can find in the room are nice (toiletries, slippers, humidifier, etc...). They even provide a free LAN cable for internet, that worked extremely well. Only issue I had was the AC not properly working. Not sure why that is, but the air does seem to get stuffy and I had to have a window open most of the time. Staff was very helpful and they speak english.All in all, good value hotel to spend a couple nights. Do not plan to stay a whole week there though or you might get claustrophobic.

First of all, the staff were polite and the location is good. Have to say that, but what we were amazed at was the fact that they switched off the air conditioning at a central point for the whole building except for a short time each day! (The temperature dial on the wall was not used so a staff member told us) So during the night the room was very stuffy and we had an unpleasant nights sleep, to say the least. When we rang down to ask about this they said they would come up and unlock a window which they did but this room was 10 floors up and there was no safety bar across the window which was rather scary and of course all the street noise came in as well. Even when we came back after shopping a few hours later we thought it may be on...but no.So even tho we had paid 2 nights we didnt stay and got another hotel via the internet for our 2nd night.

The hotel is in Ginza, in the heart of the most famous shopping area of Tokyo. Very convenient position for the subway, Ginza Line and Yurakucho Line are very close. Stayed on 13 (last) floor, the rooms were recently renovated, even if the bathromm shows its age. Good English of the Reception Desk, very kind and helpful as usual in Japan. Indeed a very good price for the area (booking with Expedia and together with the flight); excellent value for money.Good bathroom amenities and wi-fi was working excellently (could use skype easily to call home), despite other non positive reviews.As the hotel is a small one, no Limousine bus stop to/from the airport and they do exchange foreign currency at the Front Desk

this hotel is only 10 minutes walk from Tokyo station and 3 subway stops away from fish market. a lot of restaurants in this area. The location is excellent. When we arrived, it was too early to check in. People at the front desk helped us to hold our luggage, so we could go out. When we came back, our luggage was already in our room. The room is clean and bed is comfortable. people work at the front desk speak good English and very helpful. check in and check out are very quick.Tokyo is a very expensive city. With this price, I don't think you can find any hotel better than this one in Ginza area. I stayed 5 nights in ANA intercontinental tokyo and 1 night in this hotel. I think I like this hotel better.

Great location between Tsukiji fish market and Ginza shopping. You can walk to market for tuna auction at 4 in the morning! Very close to three subway stations including JR Yamanote which is free if you have Japan Rail Pass. Ginza line goes directly to Asakasa - a 'must see' old Tokyo area.Rooms are small but this is Japan and normal. Bath/shower is great to soak in at the end of the day of sightseeing!

For the money you're paying I don't think that you will find a better hotel in the Ginza area: 3 minutes walk from the main shopping area and10 minutes walk from Tokyo station, the metro is also next door.Service was excellent, the rooms small but clean and comfortable, there are numerous cafes and restaurants close by. I would definitely return.The Monteray chain seemed to cater for mostly Japanese guests, which I preferred, however, English was spoken and the staff were very helpful in recommending restaurant suggestions.

You may be shocked if you land here on your first trip to Japan. But to the seasoned traveler, this is a nice little hotel in the best possible location. The rooms are small, but not too small, and very well appointed and cared for. The reception is a bit cramped at times, and English here is really a foreign language; but they try their best and we got our room in no time. Breakfast is a mixed affair, catering to all tastes; so you will find a good continental breakfast as well as a good Japanese one, if you are up to it. I cannot comment on the restaurant: being in the very heart of Ginza, it seemed a little silly to eat at the hotel. Wifi is a hit and miss affair: it seem to be only available in the reception area, and occasionally in the breakfast room. But there is free wifi almost everywhre else in Tokyo, so this is no big deal. Al in all a very good choice for the price.

We stayed at this hotel for 4 nights and really enjoyed it. It was clean, a nice bathroom and good value and a great location. It is a 10 min walk from Tokyo station and easy to catch the metro to other parts of Tokyo. The staff was very friendly and helpful! Lots of places to shop and eat in the area. We found a fabulous wine bar across the street from the hotel, called Wine at Ginza, absolutely fabulous place to eat and drink! We can really recommed this hotel if you want a perfect location and don´t want to spend a fortune on hotel costs!

The Hotel Monterey Ginza was an excellent choice. It was clean and neat, and good value compared to other options when we booked. The view from our room wasn't great, but we didn't spend a lot of time there except for sleeping (We're in Tokyo after all). A huge plus is being close to the transit station where you can easily get to many tourist spots.

We stayed October 2010 just for the record. The room was quite nice with lovely tiles in the bathroom. I remember the hotel staff were very helpful. The tv was limited with English channels but that was okay. It was well located in Ginza and was quite affordable.Love the faux French style of the outside.

We were very happy with our standard room at this hotel, it was quite tiny, but clean with a nice bathroom and good working airconditioner. We loved the location because it was so close to Ginza station, which bascially takes you everywhere around Tokyo, and there were also many cafés (starbucks), restaurants, Izakaya's and supermarkets nearby (even 2 24/7 supermarket across from the hotel), so everything was in handreach, perfect for a week's stay in Tokyo!

The location is good, but not great--it's really close to one of the exits of Ginza Icho-me station but that metro stop isn't all that convenient, and that particular exit itself is actually quite a walk from the station. But the hotel is within walking distance to Ginza metro stop and all the nice shops on Chuo-dori. Lots and lots of restaurants and convenience stores within close proximity. Now, the rooms are TINY (though bigger than hotels within similar price range in the area), we got a double room in the annex (shin-kan) and it was 20m2. Lots of amenities (toiletries, pyjamas, slippers, newspapers) which is nice. Three things that should be mentioned are: 1, the room is not functional at all. No space to put clothes (a tiny tiny wardrobe to hang clothes, no drawers for putting clothes), the entrance hall is big but I wish they'd use that space to put a bigger and more functional wardrobe or to increase the main room size. 2, the drain didn't work very well--after I took a bath the drain back-washed so the bathroom was flooded! Fortunately nothing major. 3, if you are staying for more than three nights they require a full payment for the rooms upon check-in. The hotel was very quiet and I heard no noise from neighbours, which was nice. Super comfortable bed. I would recommend the hotel to anyone looking for a decently-priced hotel in a good location.

We stayed at the hotel to celebrate our wedding anniversary. We had dinner not at the restaurant in the hotel but they have one on the first floor. And of course eating places are everywhere since it is in the heart of Ginza district.The location is very good for visiting anywhere in Tokyo, too. You can get anywhere easily with Metro. Our room had twin beds and it was non-smoking room. It was big enough for a couple, bath room was clean and modern with a big bath tub.It was quiet at night even in the middle of Ginza district. You can get things you need from convenience stores around the hotel.People working at the front desk was good ( polite but not as friendly as Monterey Akasaka which is our favorite, too ) and helped their customers.If you are with a car, you can get very inexpensive price for the parking with the stay at the hotel. Ginza is interesting place to explore, there are not only famous brand shops but also small shops on the alleys. I recommend to have a lot of times there with staying nice and comfortable hotel like Monterey Ginza.

This hotel locates right in the middle of Ginza. Also close to Tokyo station - around 800yen by taxi or 160yen by subway.Room is not that big, but think about its location, it is understandable. Convenience stores and many places to eat around the hotel.

Hotel was in a very convenient location, staff spoke good English, room was a bit small but very clean. My wife left some clothing and we called 4 days later and they still had it and mailed it to us! Overall a great stay and would highly recommend it!

Nice budget hotel, clean and quiet, very modern. Location, in the heart of the Ginza district, could not be better - shops, restaurants, metro stops are all a short distance. Room was VERY small. Major problem, at least for me, was one of the most uncomfortable mattresses I have ever (tried to) sleep on. If you suffer from morning back aches, best to avoid this one. Hopefully they improve this.

This is one of the best value for money hotels that our family have ever stayed in. It's in a great location, the room has all amenities required, the internet connection is super-fast, and the staff are very helpful. We will definitely stay here again when we next visit Tokyo.

A great location in Ginza, very central. I had booked a double room originally for two people, and my friend canceled and didn't come. There was barely enough room in the 'double room' for just myself. However, it is, comparatively within this expensive and dense city, a good price. Lots of small extras like toiletries and pyjamas (?!) but no breakfast included. I stayed here because of the proximity to the conference centre and easy access to public transportation to see the sights in the city. If you are an architecture buff, the area boasts many fine buildings by well known architects and the iconic Nagakin capsule tower from the metabolism movement.

We stayed here for one night on our way through Tokyo to Kyoto. We spent our morning before checkout walking over to Tsukiji which is kit far at all. We have stayed in 4 different areas of Tokyo and this is by far the nicest.The sidewalks are wide and clean. It was also very close to many subway options and walkable with a rolling bag to Tokyo Station.

nice room at this very central hotel - if you like big luxury brand shopping then this is a good place for you. it's also near very nice coffee places. the hotel is generally well kept. don't expect any large public areas but rooms are goods sized (for tokyo) and the double bed was a double bed. unfortunately, the service varied - ranging from very friendly and knowledgable to quite unhelpful.

Really great location in Ginza (sort of the Knightsbridge of Tokyo). Really close to the metro and great for high end shopping.The hotel is a bit tired but for the price (£90) I really couldn't complain about that. The room is quite small but that's pretty much standard for Tokyo. I really liked this hotel and would definitely stay here again if I was in Tokyo.

My daughter and I stayed here for 4 nights this April 2012. It's about a 15 minute walk from Tokyo station. There is a metro 1 block down. There are alot of High end shops nearby. There is a great coffee show one block away. So we had a full size room in the newer remodel portion of the hotel. It is small but that is Japan. It worked well for location.

Very great location if you focus on traveling at the east side of Tokyo. It's very close to the metro station (1min walk), and very close to Tokyo station. The price is also great since we've got 40% off discount. However, the bed and pillow are a little bit too firm and makes the night less comfortable....

hotel is ok, clean, rooms are very small but there is all you need. lots of amenities in the bathroom. Considering prices in Ginza area, this hotel is reasonable.it is very close to 3 different metro station of 3 lines so it makes it easy to go wherever you want. Closest line is Yurakucho, station Ginza Hitchome is only 30 seconds away from hotel door (exit 11) . If you are at Ginza station on Maronuchi line take exit A12. Also Higashi Ginza on Hibya line is within walking distance.Things I haven't liked are 2:1-very expensive breakfast, the equivalent of 22 euros (we chooses to go to starbucks which is just a couple of minutes away and accepts credit cards)2-if you don't expressly ask for a non smoking room, you will be given a smoking room in a smoking floor. It has happened to us and they told us they were fully booked so we have to stay there, so badly smelling. Once home, I had to wash all my clothes. so make sure that you request for a non smoking room

Tokyo size room ( small) better suited for solo traveller with little lugage. If you fit that description then it's very comfortable. Bed are also on the very-firm side. Breakfast is very diverse and no so expensive for Tokyo (1500 yens) , most guest seemed to have a voucher so maybe you can get it cheaper ( I booked trough expedia and there was no option for breakfast. Internet is free but with cable (no wireless). 5 min walking to JR station and only 10-15 to Tokyo station. 3 block from Ginza street. Great!

While the hotel was conveniently located, I cannot forgive it for demanding a surcharge to check in early. Check in was nominally at 3 pm. We were there at 12 noon after flying all night. They told us our room would be ready in a half an hour, but if we wanted to check in before 3, we would have to pay a surcharge. (We dragged ourselves out shopping for a few hours instead.) I have NEVER encountered such a foolish requirement. I didn't demand a rebate when I left two hours before check-out time! That stupid surcharge requirement ruined our whole stay and our opinion of the hotel. I urge a boycott by TripAdvisor members until this ill-advised surcharge is eliminated.

The hotel is located very close to shinkansen station (20 min walk or 5 min by cab) in a very classy area with global brands and nice small cafes and restaurants. The hotel staff was neutral. They were helpful but didn't smile much. Great value for many - we got a very good deal by booking in advance. Rooms and bathroom were nice and clean. Not very spacious but it's Japan after all. Close to Tsukiji Fish Market which makes it easier for your early morning trip, close to Kabuki theatre, close to metro station.

On a quiet street walking distance from Tokyo train station. It's mainly a hotel for laying your head down I would say, the rooms are a little small and could do with repaint but the hotel has a bit of character and a sweet location that carrys it. Also very clean and apart from a few wall scratches and the like the rooms and general layout is very nice. Very good Lawson opposite for picking up bits and pieces (it's some kind of swish Tokyo version with loads of toasted cheese sandwiches and ale, I almost wept, I don't get out of rural Japan much).Not sure about breakfast but I was up and out early. Pricewise, it's surprisingly good for the location and the decor.
Nice place, good location, shopping area. Small rooms but clean enough.complete with towels, toiletries

Good location, near to Tokyo Station (15 min walk) and with a Metro Station a few meters/yards away. A Lawson, a Family Mart, cafes, restaurants, just around the corner. And Ginza Street a 5 minute walk.The staff is very polite (as usual in Japan) and can communicate in English. We noticed that about half of the Hotel was refurbished, but unfortunately we got an older room. Not comfortable and because of the earthquake (or so they said) they were keeping the room hotter than usual. We couldn't sleep during the first night (28 Celsius inside, 3 Celsius outside!). After our request to lower the temperature, they said they couldn't but could send someone to open the window and keep it that way. Since this was a quiet street, this fit the bill. We could now control room temperature using curtains and window.I guess the new rooms are a lot better.The lobby is very poor and uncomfortable if you have to wait for someone for more than a few minutes.In short: if you get a good price, and stays out of the hotel most of the time, the friendliness of staff makes you stay bearable

If looking for a clean and reasonable hotel in Ginza/Tsukiji area, this hotel is a good choice.The room is rather small with little view, but nicely decorated with dark wood floor.Big plus for a real hair dryer (not the one attached to the wall), a febreze bottle, and an air purifier/humidifier.Location is perfect, within walking distance both to Ginza shopping district and Tsukiji fish market. There are two convenience stores just across the street.Breakfast is standard buffet style.A bit disappointing if you only choose western food but Japanese food menu is decent.

Stayed here for three nights understanding that we were paying for location. That said, we found the front desk oddly unable to help with basic directions or recommendations. While they eventually were able to assist, we felt like we were the first people to ever ask questions like "can you suggest a good shabu shabu restaurant", or "how do we take the river cruise". Most annoying was the air conditioning. Don't bother with the controls in the room. The air conditioning (or lack there of) is controlled at the front desk. If your room is too hot or too cold, you have to call down to have them adjust. This is not explained at check-in.

The hotel is in a great area. It's a 5-10 minute walk from the Tokyo train station. However, from Narita aiport, I took a bus (1 hour) and it dropped us off within a 5 minute walk from the hotel. The neighborhood is great. The hotel isn't on a large street. The small street the hotel is located on is bustling yet quiet. There's a lot of shops, and a convenient store right across the street from the hotel, and a starbucks and a mcdonalds 3-4 blocks away.The hotel staff was great. Their english was limited but sufficient to communicate and guide me on where to go. The hotel room, like all Japanese hotel rooms was a small, but well laid out. I've been in similar size hotel rooms in Hong Kong, and they felt way smaller because their use of space was so poorly thought out. The was very clean and nice. Nothing to take pictures of, and nothing to complain about.

New York City, New York

review_body: Just arrived from a great vacation in Osaka, weather was great too! The hotel is great, very nice, clean, and good service, most of all good location, just in the center of all we need. Close to the train stations which makes it easy to move around. The supermarket at bl has all good stuff. Thanks , the reviews helped us find a good hotel. Hope this helps others too!

We were stayed at this hotel for a week, overall was quite a good location if you love to do shopping at Ginza. This was my first time stayed in this hotel but for the cleanliness i will prefer Hotel Comfort that i been stayed for few times. Location was good, opposite have Family Mart and Lowson. Staff were being quite helpful too :-) if you really like to stay at Ginza, is consider not bad.

Hotel Monterey Ginza is not a 5 star hotel but a twin size room with breakfast in the heart of Ginza district for 16000 yen is a good value (Aug. 2011) The decor was tired and out-dated a little. Our first room's bathroom was clogged, the bedside walls had a bizarre stain (some kind of big splash - can't be water...maybe sake or some kind of alcohol), the furniture had wear and tear, so we requested for a room change. The new room still looked tired but we didn't complain. It seems like the hotel is often used for weddings and tour groups but we didn't mind. It was nice to be able to go back to the hotel after a nice and long dinner in Ginza but would I go back? Maybe not. I probably would pay 15000 yen more and stay at the Imperial where you get better rooms and service.

I stayed at this hotel before, and again i had a chance to stay here. It's in front of the Metro station 'Ginza Icchome' (Yurakucho Line), but if you are taking Ginza line or Marunouchi Line, or JR (Yurakucho station), it's still easy to walk to the hotel, pretty close from Ginza main street (Chuo-Dori).Room is not described as gorgeous, but is comfortable and stylish, makes you feel at home. The location is very nice. It has NATURAL LAWSON right in front of the hotel, which is a specical convinence store providing lots of organic food and cosmetics, also a wide variety of wines and juice, original mineral water, etc. At the hotel Wall Street Journal newspaper was provided for free. I can understand why this hotel attracts lots of international customers.

Stayed for 3 nights recently for a short tourist visit. The hotel is located in the heart of Giza on a small side street and is easy walking distance from the Ginza subway station (exit A13). Although folks used to American hotels may find the room and bathroom to be small, they are well designed and do not lack any amenities. There are many places to eat around the hotel catering to all budgets. The front desk staff was helpful with advice and making arrangements for airport transfers. The wired internet in the room was fast and free. I would happily stay here again.
Very nice and quite. Helpfull staff. Good communication. Fri internet (compare with USA where you have to pay at the most places). Overall a good hotell.

The hotel is located two minutes' walk from Ginza's main thoroughfare, Chuo Dori and is also within walking distance of three subway stations: Ginza, Higashi Ginza and Ginza-Itchome (this last one is the closest). Also no more than a 10 minute walk from Yurakucho Station which is on the JR Yamanote Line (loop line). So there are plenty of department stores, convenience stores and places to eat nearby (of course, this being Ginza, the department stores are on the expensive side). Though travelling alone, I had a basic double room which was very comfortable, clean and smart. The staff were helpful at the front desk. I did not eat in the hotel simply because there are so many other options nearby. I had breakfast at the Doutor coffee shop one minute's walk away and visible from the hotel entrance. I have stayed at this hotel chain once previously and had a similarly comfortable experience.

A boutique hotel in Ginza, a very upscale exclusive area of Tokyo. Rooms however were Very, very small, but extremely clean. Very nice toiletries, slippers and even pajamas!!!The hotel was only a couple of blocks away from the all the high end shops, the Rodeo Drive of Tokyo. Also a plethora of restaurants from which to choose.

this hotel located near the glamourous Ginza street! literally,,only 2 minutes walk!plenty of restaurants around this area..as well as a walking distance to the Yarakucho train station. room is very clean, breakfast...reasonable price. staff very friendly and speak English well. will defintely stay at this hotel again :)

This time around it was our honeymoon, the room was small but functional. The service was sufficient for the price range. The location is unbeatable. The hotel is situated in the glitzy Ginza area where hotels usually come at a premium. The hotel has the basic amenities and if you are missing anything there are 2 7-11 type stores right across the street. The side streets are very quiet. There are many restaurants on Ginza, however there is a fabulous old Edo style restaurant kiddy corner to the hotel at the subway entrance on the B2 level, prices are reasonable and the decor is very original. Tsukiji Market is walking distance and is open very early for those North Americans who are jet lagged on their first few days. The Ginza (orange line) is the most convenient line to reach the Asakusa, Ueno, Harajuku districts. The closest entrance is on the main Ginza drag approximately 10 minute walk from the hotel. For anybody looking for a great value, no frills, basic amenities, and excellent location this is the place to stay.

We loved this hotel for it's prime location and the great rooms. It's literally a one minute walk to the main shopping street in Ginza and only 30 secs more to a main metro station. It was great value on agoda with good sized rooms that were kept very clean. Our only gripe was that the room got very hot however we asked them to open a locked window which solved the problem.
It is about 10mins walk to Ginza station if you walk fast enough. Hotel is in a quieter street and hence you should be able to sleep well. Bed was queen-sized but still good enough for both of us.

I stayed here and it was awful.The toilet was a disgrace as the smell of the drains were so over-powering, it woke me on several occasions over the night.The staff simply put on the old, I don't understand response which did nothing to help.Sure it's cheap, but as a result it attracts some colorful clientele.I am very well traveled, but this place made me feel nervous.Mercure is just around the corner, I should have stayed there instead.

My fiance and I stayed here in May 2010 for a week. The location is amazing and for the value. It is walking distance to many major attractions and the train. We would start our day with breakfast at the nearby outer Tsukiji market ( as for we wer jet lagged and that was guaranteed to be open bright and early 5AM). from there we caught the ferry from the neighboring gardens to Asakusa or we would take the train to other areas of the city. The transit system is very convenient and thee was always a transit worker at the gates to ask questions if you weren't able to figure out how the machine worked or how much you needed to pay to get to your destination. One wor dof advice is not to take the train to Shinjuku during rush hour as for it is very cramped. One more word we loved Tokyo so much that we are headed back there in May and of course staying at the Monterey Ginza again . . .

Family of 4, mum & dad + 2 teenage boys on the way to the snow. We had 3 nights at Monterey Ginza from 23 Jan 2011. Service...impecable, the front desk staff had varying degrees of english but the message always got through and their desire to please was fantastic - very polite, very willing. We had 2 rooms, one double and one twin, both non smoking. Small but adequate. The twin room was actually bigger than the double. Wired free internet to the room. The rooms were very clean - a few minor scrapes down the walls but with the size of the rooms that is understandable with the amount of travellers coming in and out. The position is great, Metro stations very handy, McDonalds and Starbucks close and plenty of very reasonably priced Japanese restaurants within easy walking distance. We had stunning Sushimi at the Japanese restaurant directly opposite the entrance and down a stairwell - very reasonable price, no other tourists - just a bit smokey from the local businessmen but fantastic meal. I note another reviewer was not happy with the service but our experience was fantastic. We arrived at midnight after a flight delay and there were still 2 staff on the front desk and no they did not help with the luggage - we had a lot, 4 bags and 4 snowboard bags but I did not expect this at a 3 star Hotel. They booked us a taxi Van for our departure due to all of our luggage not fitting into a normal taxi (car). They had metro maps avaialble, in both English and Japanese and were very helpful in giving us directions. All said, Hotel Montery Ginza is exceptional value for money, ($200 NZD per night per room via Expedia) and we highly rate it!!

This review is a little late! We stayed here for 5 nights in May of 2010. This hotel has an excellent location. It’s clean, with basic amenities. The room was smaller than the one we had while in Kyoto. The price is very reasonable. Keep in mind it’s not a flashy hotel. I love the PJ’s you are provided to wear.

The Moneterey should not be marketed as a hotel (3 stars no less), it is more like a Motel. There is no service to speak of, the front desk staff just laugh at you whenever you ask them for anything - 1) early check in : no, check in is at 3pm ( we notice 4 couples checking out when we checked in, so how a room can't be available escapes me), 2) electrical adapter: none that work available, 3) help with luggage: nobody lifted a finger to help with luggage or to get a cab when we checked out, even though we obviously had ski gear to manage on top of our luggage. I find it shocking that some basic service standards can't even be met. The staff are shockingly lazy and rude when compared to the high service standards you get elsewhere in Japan - the convenience store clerk was more helpful. They can't even provide a basic English language map of Tokyo considering the number of foreign guests that stay there - they told my husband to go to the nearest bookstore and buy one!The only good thing about the hotel is its location, although there are other hotels close by, so I would recommend you try those rather than the Monterey. The rooms, though clean, are tiny and forget about fitting 2 normal size individuals on the double bed.We stayed at the Monterey as a last resort as we went to Tokyo on a last minute whim during the festive season and could not get other accommodation near Tokyo Station/Ginza. We will be sure to stay somewhere else in future.

The location of the hotel was good and the price was very reasonable considering the Ginza location. The hotel was quite easily reachable from the Narita airport. We took a Narita express to the Tokio station. The room was small but very clean and it had all the things you need. We had a double bed and that was a bit too small (smaller than a normal size) for what we are used to. The pillows were not for our liking either because they were quite hard. We called them "futon" pillows. The price didn't include the breakfast and we didn't try it because there were grocery stores and cafes on the other side of the street. The main department stores and the Ginza shopping streets were basically next door. The closest metro (Ginza itshome) entrance was about 20 meters from the hotel door but that line was not the most convenient for sightseeing. On the other hand it took only a short walk to reach the really useful lines. There was a computer available for the guests but it was not for free.

Location,location,location. It is good that after a long flight you really instantly at ease with your hotel location and this is what we felt about the Monterey.We found the rooms a decent size after reading comments about lack of room and the hotel was clean, quiet with good service from reception .I would describe it as no frills but it was a decent place to stay and all the adventure was out and about in Tokyo.We had 2 stays on our trip and checked in at mid day and 1pm and was not quizzed about early book in.

We stayed in Monterey Ginza Hotel for our 9 night stay in Tokyo. Great value booking through HotellClub.com.au.Reception staff all spoke adequate English for us to get by. The hotel has style, modelled on Parisian hotels from around the 1900's. It is very clean, and the rooms, while being compact, were by no means the smallest we had in Japan. We would not hesitate to recommend this hotel.

Stayed at this hotel for the first 5 nights of our honeymoon trip in Japan.Really liked the place, unusually they let us check-in early for no charge (12.00 instead of 15.00) which was a great help after the long flight from UK.Staff were always friendly, even arranging the forwarding of luggage to Kyoto for us for the following week.Lots of shops and restaurants nearby for all budgets even though you are in Ginza!!Big plus point...the hotel is walking distance to Tsukiji (sp) fish market which is very handy indeed as well as very handy for several metro lines.Overall a great base in a very comfortable hotel!!

Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom

review_body: Spent six nights at the Monterey last week with the family we were impressed with the location, so close to the subway stations. Quiet in the rooms no traffic noises at all, clean and tidy, friendly staff and just the best. A fabulous place to stay, close to lots of great places to eat at all reasonable priced. Even though the staff spoke little English, they always try to accommodate any requests and put in a big effort to please you.A BIG thumbs up to the Monterey team..

This hotel is located in the centre of Ginza which is the centre of Tokyo and is close to the subway for travel to any location. The hotel has reasonable sized rooms with all of the amenities you would expect with the exception of a safe in the room. I was on Level 8 with a backward facing room so there was no view available but then I did not come to the hotel to look at the view. The lift is an older style lift of a bygone era which was a pleasure to ride in. The thing that lets the hotel is the lack of a decent front entry. It is almost as if the hotel was hiding from the world with only a standard width door on the street front. The reception area is also quite small. The staff are very easy to deal with and are very helpful.The bed was very comfortable to sleep in. The room had a cable internet connection that was fairly fast at no additional cost. There was cable TV provided with world news only in English but if movie channels were want they cost 1000 yen per day. This is a very high cost for entertainment. I would go back to this hotel because of its location and reasonable sized rooms.

The hotel is conveniently located. Close to main shopping street and 3 metro stations. You can easily travel to Roppongi Hills, fish market, and other main sightseeing spots.The rooms are clean and puristic, but I really liked the design.

The hotel is in a fantastic location- 3 different subway stations all within walking distance. It is so easy to get to places from Ginza. There are 2 convenience stores right across the road, which does good pastries for breakfast. There are plenty of department stores and restaurants in Ginza and it always feels very safe. The hotel is off the main road, so stays fairly quiet. The staff at reception are all very friendly and helpful and all spoke pretty good english. The bedrooms were very basic and seemed a little tired, but had everything you would need. The tea and coffee making facilities were good. I think the bedrooms could do with a good lick of paint, as there were several marks on the walls. However, the bathroom was in an excellent state and seemed very stylish. The room was cleaned well and the pyjamas and slippers were changed everyday. Overall, the hotel is a great hotel if you're going to be out exploring everyday and not really spending too much time in the hotel, but if you're after a more relaxing time, I would suggest going somewhere which is a bit more special and would offer more comfort. If I go back to Tokyo, I would stay at the Monterey again. It suited us for what we wanted to do and it's a great price for it's central location.

Great little hotel that offers decent value given what it offers and its perfect location in Ginza which means it is convenient to travel anywhere around Tokyo. The service is efficient and prompt in typical Japanese style. The location is fantastic - very convenient to be in Ginza as you can get anywhere in Tokyo fairly easily. Ginza is a very stylish area of Tokyo and is very nice to walk around in - the area is clean and has a lot of interesting stores. Also, it needs to be mentioned that there are 2 convenience stores directly opposite the hotel - makes it very easy for any guests to pick up any essentials (such as beer) aswell as non-essentials (such as drinking water).The rooms are a bit small but it would be considered to be normal size for a Japanese hotel room. Otherwise, the rooms are clean and comfortable. We have no complaints about the room we were given. The rooms come with free internet access (via ethernet) - this proved to be very useful for us during our trip to Japan. Costs seems to be reasonable for Ginza - my girlfriend and I paid approximately AU$145 per night per room.Overall we were very satisfied with our stay at the Monterey Ginza. We would definitely consider this place again when we next visit Tokyo.

I personally don't like too large hotel, with many large conference rooms, and banquet rooms, too many esalaters and elevators, for it exhaust me sometimes. So, when you want to stay in a relaxed mood, don't want to ask staff `where's an elevator' or ask to yourself `which restaurant offer best morning buffet?', and when you don't walk more than 1 km inside the hotel which is farer than from the nearest station...., this can be a good choice. Lovely confortable small hotel, but with some desigh, sophistication. The breakfast was really good. They have wide variety of healthy high quality food. Tomato was special, bread was special... I am very particular about food, but they certainly satisfied me.

Good: Not quite as quirky and interesting as we'd read on Trip Advisor and seen in various hotel pix, but still a good hotel at a reasonable price in the heart of Ginza right near the subway. No breakfast or room service of any description but late night convenience stores nearby and also some noodle restaurants.Not so good: check in time is 3pm. Any earlier costs Y1000 per hour. Lobby area smelled badly of cigarette smoke but not in the rooms. Room was quite small but probably normal by Japanese standards.Would stay there again I guess which says something.

This hotel is good if you remember that it is Tokyo after all. The rooms are small and the bed is pushed up against the wall which makes for uncomfortable sleeping, especially if you're American and are used to large beds. The bathroom is also tiny but it has everything one would need. The hotel is very clean with the exception that the entryway often smells of cigarette smoke. They have designated non smoking floors though. It is located centrally and very close to subways and walking distance to the major Ginza shopping district.

This hotel was in a good, easy to find location in Ginza, just a few blocks away from high-end shopping. It is within walking distance to Tokyo Station and Ginza Metro line, which will get you anywhere you need to go in the city as well as high-speed trains to Kyoto and beyond. Rooms are small, but certainly not the smallest on my trip to Japan (space is at a premium here, one has to get used to that!). Staff are friendly, speak good English, and got a kick out of our attempts at speaking Japanese. My only complaint isn't with the hotel itself but the neighborhood--as someone who was on a budget, it was difficult to find inexpensive restaurants and bars. We usually ate breakfast at the Lawson's convenience store right across the street and inexpensive dinners could be found on the restaurant floors of the nearby department stores.Overall, a great stay and the hotel made a great base for exploring the city.

great location and the room was somewhat small, but the space worked. Most importantly, the bed was good and the shower had some nice power! we've stayed in this hotel for 4 days and liked it most for it's location. a lot of nice restaurants nearby and the subway is around the corner. it's in between the fish market and the castle and tokyo central station. we liked it a lot. we didn't use the hotel restaurant, so we can't comment on that. for its location, price and room- / bedsize i would classify it as a very good option!

Small, but clean rooms, decorated in a minimalistic Japanese vibe; a very nice (albeit small) bathroom, in stylish black. Quiet too, it's on a side street in Ginza that pretty much "closes" for the night. If I remember right, there were at least two 24h convenience stores right across the street, as well as some very touristy restaurants. Location-wise, there is actually a Metro station stop (the Line name escapes me) right across the street, but it's not really the best way to move about - your best bet is to walk a bit further until you reach the Ginza Line stop which a small walk away in the heart of Ginza. In terms of nightlife, Ginza isn't the best choice, because if you're out and about in Shibuya or Shinjuku for example and miss the last train...you're "stranded" quite far from your hotel, you'll have to take a relatively expensive taxi to get home.Annoyingly, I had some trouble sleeping (on several nights actually), but it might've been just me, not the hotel. The hotel itself is no-frills type of place, you won't find a huge fitness center or a swimming pool here. But that was perfect for me, since I only wanted a clean & quiet base to stay after each night, nothing more. And actually, that's what I usually expect from any hotel, all around the world.The staff was, as is usually the custom for Japan, very courteous and friendly. Spoke English too. If I remember correctly, I was escorted to my taxi and even waved goodbye (lol).I'd say it's very good value for money - got a very decent rate (for May) from Hotels.com. If there's one thing I would've wished for, it would be complementary WiFi - there's an internet cable socket in the room, but that's no good if you don't have one of those with you... It's not really a big deal though, there's a laptop that you can use at the front desk, or you can just walk to the Ginza Apple Store...

Hotel Monterey Ginza was in a great location, for shopping and sight-seeing. It was easy to get around Tokyo from here either on the train or subway .It was also in a quiet spot just off the main shopping area of Ginza - wonderful for window shopping! A great western breakfast was available as well as the traditional Japanese style. Well worth staying at.

Have sayed at this hotel on my last two trips through Tokyo. Love the location, Ginza is great for both shopping and restaurants. A tip - the best restaurants are on the small side streets, not the main strips. This hotel is next to Ginaze-Itchome metro station, and is only 5-10 minute walk from Ginza metro station, which has direct links to some of the most interesting areas in Tokyo - Shibuya, Shinjuku, Ueno, Roppongi, etc. In my opinion this makes Ginza a good base for exploring Tokyo. Also the hotel is walking distance (about 15 - 20 minutes) to the Tsukiji Fish Market (a must see) and Tokyo Station (for Shinkansen trains to Kyoto, Osaka, etc). The rooms are very small but this is standard for Tokyo. The staff are helpful. There used to be free internet in the lobby but this has been replaced with a coin-operated internet computer.One major complaint - the rooms are small and get hot, but on my last visit the air conditioning was not working properly. We were told by the front desk that it was controlled by them, but when we asked them to turn the air-con up they said that they couldn't because this would cause all the other rooms to become cold. Was a bit suprised to find that rooms don't have individual climate control/air-con, have not had this problem in any other hotels in Japan. Not sure if this was a one-off problem or if this is a general problem with this hotel, but would definitely not stay here in summer if this was not fixed.
A small, well managed, hotel in a good location for exploring Tokyo by foot or any public transport.Clean neat bathroom complete with heated toilet seat etc.

We stayed at Monterey Hotel Ginza for 5 days of retail therapy, a base for sight seeing and eating the AWESOME food. For value for money, location and cleanliness you cannot beat this place. The hotel staff spoke english and gave some great recommendations on places to eat - if you like Tepenyaki a must is Chibo - Level 6 Bic Camera building. Ask for the map of Ginza at reception and use this as a point of reference when asking for anything and they will show you how to get there. The hotel is walking distance to JR Yurakucho Station and metro lines Ginza 09, Marunouchi 16, Hibiy 08 and Yurakucho 19 . I recommend getting out of the city for a day, we booked a tour with Sunrise to Fuji & Hakone that was well worth the $200 aussie dollors per head. If you like a night cap you cannot beat Nelson's Bar that is across the road from the hotel - no cover charge and all drinks and snack are 500 yen - half the price of the hotel.

This is a neat hotel, great location (Ginza and close to subway), the rooms are clean and there is free internet. They are a bit on the small side, but it's still fine for a big city hotel. The value was excellent (paid less than 70 Euro per night, which is impossible to beat in Tokyo).

My sister and I stayed at the hotel for 3 nights, from Dec. 30-Jan.2. I booked the hotel for a pretty good price considering it was during the New Year season. I ended up paying about 12,000 yen per night, which was about $130+ Good things:- Good location, right next to the subway, 10 mins walk to JR Tokyo Station, but for some reason, I kept getting lost trying to find the hotel at night- Very nice staff, very polite, okay English, but I speak Japanese to them anyway, so it was never a problem for me- The amenities in the room were very nice, they include everything that you could ask for- Room service was excellentBad things:- A double room is not that big, just enough for 2 people to get in and might have to elbow your way around a bit, even though my sisters and I are very small (we are both 5 feet, and less then 100 lbs, just imagine that)- Not much of a view from our windowOverall, I would conclude that my stay at the hotel was good, but not good enough to try to stay there again. If you know Tokyo area pretty well, I recommend the b ikebukuro, which has a slightly bigger room at a lower price. Check out my review for that hotel too.

A nice hotel with small, plain but comfortable rooms. Ginza is a very smart area and the price we paid was way below similar hotels we found nearby. Everything worked and was spotless, service was fine. The bathroom was well stocked with free toiletries that were replenished daily and the bed was very comfortable. The main attraction is the location, which is perfect for tourists like us. It’s in a very quiet back street very close to the main Ginza thoroughfares. There is a subway station 20 meters from the front door and convenience stores and western coffee shops every few steps around the area. The Yurakucho station on the JR Yamanote line is 10-15 minutes walk away. Once we learnt this we could save money on subway fares as the Yamanote line is free on the JR pass and could take us to most places we wanted to go in Tokyo.
