Cape Town Central, South Africa

review_body: Very nice French chic hotel with the Ginza main shopping street just a few steps away. There is a metro station just at the side of the hotel which is very convenient.

The hotel is very well-located pretty; near the major shopping street along Ginza. Just less than 5 mins walk and you'll reach the streets of famous shopping centre and famous brands.The rooms aren't specfiically spacious but definitely good enough for me as I understand most hotel rooms in Tokyo are relatively small. House keeping is excellent as my room is nicely cleaned. A pity they change my room slippers everyday though they can be recycled. But this is really a small issue. Overall, had a wonderful stay.

Found this hotel through the travel agent, and checked out reviews on Trip Advisor.Small hotel just off the main strip, near all the big department stores and couture boutiques. Harry Winston jewellery store is on the cornerRooms very small, but pretty typical for Japan. Free internet which was invaluable.Clean, but curtains not blackout. In summer, it's bright at 5am! We decided to go to the Fish Markets so it turned out OK.For movies, you buy a voucher from a machine in the lift lobby, but there are so many repetitive advertisements it almost wasn't worth it.Definitely a handy place for the Ginza district, but I probably would stay in another area next time I visited Tokyo

Monterey is my hotel chain of choice in Tokyo when I'm not on work (i.e. when I'm paying for myself). The Ginza hotel is like the others, clean, affordable, very Japanese and not trying to do too much. It has a well-done French theme, which is non-abtrusive for the most part. I've stayed for most of a week here, and a week at another one in Hanzomon (in Chiyoda ward of Tokyo), and it wears well as well. Not spacious - not a $400 western hotel - but the space is well-planned and that's totally fine with me. It's not located for maximum party times - this is not a hostel near Roppongi for the foreigner kids, and it's not in Shinjuku or catering to Western tourists. It does cater to Japanese and seems to have a pretty reliable clientele, and work on that basis. Staff usually speak passable English but do need to occassionally find a colleague to speak with you. It's quiet, located about a three block walk to Ginza metro hub, and right around from the world's best paper store.

I stayed at this hotel for a week on my own in a room with a double bed. The room is smallish, but was great for one person. Very clean and comfortable. The staff were courteous and helpful. Location was outstanding; near metro, main Ginza street and lots of groceries and cafes nearby.

Great location, nice hotel, very nice bathroom. They change the linen and towels and pijamas EVERYDAY, even if you do not let them on the floor, not ecological at all! The only thing that bodered me is that you can not open the windows, but I guess in all Japan hotels its like that. The staff's english was not very good, for a bigger hotel this should be necessary. If you ask for a taxi they recommend its better to call one, of course they charge 500 yens more. Itsa compeltely rip-off, as there are plenty of taxis waiting on the street and its absolutely safe. But I recommend it.

We stayed at Monterey Ginza for 8 nights in june 2009. Staff was very friendly and helpfull. Location was excellent, close to metrostation. Rooms were rather small but clean and comfortable. Every day we got english newspaper behind our door. Only bad thing was that when we first came to the hotel we had to wait our room for 2 hours. We came to Monterey Ginza at 12.00 am and got our room about 14.00 pm. After 24 hour travelling that was too much waiting..

This was a lovely place to stay. The staff were very helpful and could speak English. The room was very clean and comfortable. It is conveniently located next to a Metro station so getting around Tokyo from there by train was very easy. There are some fantastic (and very cheap!) places to eat nearby as well. There was also a laptop with internet access in the lobby for use by guests for free. This hotel was a great base for our sightseeing in Tokyo.

We stayed a couple of nights in March. The hotel is in a great location, right in the heart of Ginza. It's a short walk to various metro stops and about a 15 minute, flat walk to Tokyo Station. The room was spacious by Japanese standards and very comfortable. The bathroom was a proper one, not one of those plastic one-piece ones you find in some hotels in Japan. I left an item at the hotel, which they held for me until I could get back to collect it (although a call or email to say I'd left it would have made the service even better). The only downside is you can't control the heating or cooling from your room, but if you ask reception they will set a temperature for you. I'd definitely stay here again.

We stayed here twice during a two week stay in japan, the first time for two nights and then for another fours at the end of the trip. We really liked the hotel and its location. It is just around the corner from the main Gina shopping area and a subway station is literally round the corner.The rooms are compact but really were nice and actually much better than we had expected from what we had heard about small room sizes. We stayed in both a twin and double room and were very happy with both. They were modern and very clean with broadband access as well. Beds were comfy too and the double had a king size bed - it was up against one wall - but this did not bother us.The front desk staff were very friendly and although their english on some ocassions was not great, we found them to be helpful and professional. We got stuck a few times with communication and found writing it done helped us loads. You can't expect staff to all speak perfect english in a business type hotel.We would definately stay here again.

After staying at the monterey in Kyoto i was expecting good things!. If i could have checked out and gone somewhere else i would. Staff didn't seem bothered, lobby area small and dark. Hotel needs a total revamp, the room was a good size but very dated with wooden floor. Bathroom not overly clean and very dark, shower was useless.Off the main area and not a lot around the hotel. Best thing is the free laptop in the lobby with free internet access. Avoid if you can

My husband and I stayed at this hotel for 5 nights. It's a no frills place. The staff did not speak English very well, but they were friendly and helped when they could. They called us taxis for our early morning to the fish market and when we needed to go to Tokyo Station to get the train. I would not recommend the hotel for those who want more services. For example, they don't offer exchange services (Citibank ATM is about a 5 minute walk away.) and there aren't any safes in the rooms. They offer a small lock box at the front desk.The room was clean and sparsely decorated in an art deco style. It's a good value at about $165 US a night for its great location in Ginza. It's only a one minute walk to the Ginza-Itchome subway stop and a 5 minute walk to the Ginza subway stop, where you can get on three lines. It's only a 5 minute taxi ride from Tokyo Station. (Like a previous reviewer recommended, it's easier to take a taxi to the hotel from Tokyo Station if it's your first time there.) There are plenty of eating options around the hotel and several convenience stores nearby. I strongly recommend skipping the overpriced breakfast buffet. It's the worst buffet that we've had traveling in Asia. The Western options were limited and poorly executed. The fruit was fresh, but not worth that price, of course. We ended up getting light breakfast at some nearby coffee shops. There's a local chain and Starbucks.

Very small (think 1/2 the size of your average US hotel rooms) but clean. The best part of the hotel is its location. The hotel doesn't have a gym, but we were able to run to the Imperial Palace in under 5mins to do our morning loops around the Palace. Bed is comfortable (sheets are a little on the rough side, but after a day of walking around the city, you'll be too tired to notice it).

We were really impressed with the Hotel Monterey Ginza... - It's in an excellent location in Ginza, only 2 blocks from the main street in Ginza, yet the hotel is in a quiet street and the rooms are also free from any outside noise. It's less than 1min walk to a Ginza-itchome metro station exit & a 5 min walk to Ginza station exit (which is actually a better station as three lines converge there & better if going to Asakusa, Ueno, Tokyo stn or Shibuya). - Staff spoke fluent English & were always courteous & helpful- Classy European/French style throughout hotel. There's French-style music playing in the hallways, so it's like a little slice of Europe in Japan.- We were in a semi-double room which was very small and we were actually a little worried about how small it was going to be. Sleeping in the semi-double bed was actually fine though. It's the same length as a standard double & only 15-20cm thinner width-wise. It's fine for a couple & if neither of you are large ppl. The bed itself was very comfortable & we got 3 nights of great sleep. - Depsite the room's small size, you get used to that in Japan & the exquisite style & interior design of the room definitely made up for it. Tokyo is an awesome city so you shouldn't be spending too much time in your hotel.- Note that the safety deposit box at reception is more like an envelope that can only fit a few small objects. That's really the only thing we weren't overly impressed with...which isn't much.

I booked 2 doubles for my husband and I/sister and boyfriend and 1 single for my Mom during our 3 days in Tokyo as part of our family vacation in late October 2008. We all LOVED the Hotel Monterey Ginza! First, location couldn't be beat, it was great to be in the heart of Ginza with all the wonderful high-end shopping and so close to the train and subway stations. The hotel itself was very modern and definitely had a boutique atmosphere. The dark wood combined with French pictures and the French music as soon as I opened the door into the hallway made me feel transported to a French boulevard! The staff was very helpful and had pre-made maps to show us where to exchange money and even good restaurants to try. The room itself was VERY comfortable and a good size, with more toiletry options than I've ever seen (including hair clips!) and the air system, toilet, TV, everything was so modern! It also had a great Wi-fi internet connection that was very convenient for us. Best of all, the price was definitely right! It was a GREAT base for Tokyo and I will stay there again!

Very very small room but very clean and an excellent location for a trip to Tokyo. We didn't want to spend more than $200 per night and, if you're in the same boat, stay here. Nice english-speaking staff was very helpful.

I booked this room on Rooomstogo.com, so I got a great price. Even paying the "normal" tarif, I will still stay here. The boutique-style, Japanese hotel is in a faux-Deco style building in the Ginza. Very near to several main subway stops, with the closest entry a block away.Good area restaurants and, of course, shopping.I checked OUT of the nearby, and soul less, Marriott in favor of a more local experience. The hotel staff here were courteous, English was fine, and I was able to get all of my business requirements met here. Good internet (and free, unlike the Marriott), good food, phone.Room was small, but this IS Tokyo. Stylishly decorated, with a flat-screen, HD TV, ensuite bath (with a cool heated and plumbed toilet seat).Great value in a lovely hotel.

This hotel is right in the heart of Ginza area. II took the JR line to Tokyo station and then took a taxi to the hotel. If you are travelling to this hotel for the first time and not familier with the Japan Subway system, then I would recommend the same. Once I got to the hotel and got a feel for the place, it was a breeze for me to take the subway. The closest subway entrance is about 1 minute by walk from the hotel. The hotel was very clean and the staff were extremly efficient. The check in and check out were fast. The staff all spoke English and were helpful in giving directions, tips on using the subway, shopping recommendations, etc. I booked the hotel room with the breakfast package which I recommend. The breakfast was fantastic and had both Japanese and European breakfast. The room came with hi-speed internet access and it was included in my room rate. The rooms were small compared to American standards, but it was plenty for a me. The bathroom was nice with heated toilet seat and was very clean. The hotel did not have any safes in the room, but they do have a service which allows you to leave your valuables with the hotel. Overall, I will say this is an excellent hotel for the value.

I booked a double room at the Monterey Ginza because it was included in a vacation deal, without really knowing what I was going to find. Me and my husband enjoyed an amazing time there from the moment we arrived. The service was great, with a very polite and helpful staff, although a little Japanese knowledge is useful since their English-speaking skills are not that great. They can say "good morning" and "enjoy your stay", but when I asked them to recharge my MP3 at their computer's USB, they were kind of lost, just like the time when I tried to ask them to call me a cab: I ended up doing that in Japanese. As far as location is concerned, it just couldn't be better. You are minutes away from the main hubs in the terrible hell of the Tokyo subway, so it's really easy to travel with as less connections as possible, and the streets around the place are crowded not only with shops but with great cozy, Japanese, low-priced restaurants, as well as the best of all: two convenience stores opened 24 hours a day right in front of the hotel doors, so you can buy a banana, a face mask or a bottle of water whenever you need to.We had a double room and it was fully equipped with anything from a big kettle to a proper hairdryer, and a flat-screen TV, although the closet was kind of small for our 10-days stay. The bed was great, and the bathroom had anything you could ask for, from hair clips to a warm WC seat!! We didn't have breakfast or any meal included so I can't provide an opinion on that, but my guess is the restaurant was good from what I heard from other guests.There are internet facilities free of charge in the reception area, which was great for us since our cell phones didn't work while we were there.We spent a night away at the Hakone National Park and we couldn't wait to go back to the Monterey Ginza, we ended up calling it "home", because that is exactly what it felt like.All in all, it was a great experience and very affordable, I would truly recommend it to anyone.Virginia

A gem of a hotel right in the centre of Tokyo.Small reception area staff very friendly polite and helpful.Subway station seconds walk Tokyo main railway station 10mins walk and Ginza shopping area 2mins walk.Rooms small well appointed and air conditioned (this is important in Tokyo ) bed was a bit neat for a european frame but comfortable nevertheless hotel quiet.Restaurant a bit pricey but area is surrounded by restaurants bars coffee shops and a couple convenience stores accross street which are open 24/7.

Monterey Hotels in Japan are known for European style and reasonable cost. I've stayed at the Monterey in Sapporo and in Sendai (both great experiences) and the Ginza Monterey simple doesn't compare. Rooms are small and business-hotel-like (in the cramped Japanese sense) and I had a double. Dull best describes the room. I reserved non-smoking and got a smoking room. The TV had BBC World but every time I hit the sub button for English it reverted to Japanese within a minute. And I was requested to pay the equivalent of $500 U.S. upfront (without even seeing my room) as 'policy of the hotel', despite the fact that I have both a permanent Japanese address and solid Japanese ability. A credit card imprint was not enough, I was billed the moment I signed in. This is the only hotel to ever request that of me in Japan and I've lived here for 11 years. Basically, the hotel needs to be renovated. It was probably a much nicer place in the 1970s. The hotel is convenient for Ginza shopping, but there are much better hotels available at roughly the same cost.

I would recommend this hotel to family and friends. It's central location makes it a gem, not to mention the reasonable price. From the Ginza Itchome metro, take exit 11 and turn right. It's just two short blocks from there (1 minute walk). Hotel staff were hospitable and helpful. As per other reviews, don't take the breakfast; it's not worth $20. Try the McDonald's or Starbuck's, both a minute or two away by foot.The room itself is simple yet comfortable and ultraclean. I asked for a quiet room and found myself on the 12th floor, far above any of the minor traffic noise below; it's a very quiet area in any event. But a mere five minutes away and you are on Ginza Dori, the Oxford Street or Park Aveneue of Tokyo. Connections from the nearby Ginza metro (exit 13 is most convenient to hotel) are excellent. Overall, I would stay here again without hesitation. A very comfortable, clean and quiet hotel.

Great boutique hotel with atmosphere and location. Just off the Ginza and within walking distance to metro and JR line. Deco is 1930's touches throughout. Rooms are well appointed, quiet and with small modern bathroom. Excellent service.

The great value and location were what made this hotel. In a quiet street just off the Ginza and literally meters to the subway or within a five minute walk to a major station (saves more time-consuming changing), this hotel had good local shops nearby and it was very easy to get taxis. It's not flash, but neither is it basic - it is a tourist class hotel. The bathroom was good for a hotel of this class. The internet access is very good, but if you bring your own LAN cable you'll get connected a lot faster (they loan them from reception). Our only complaints were that the breakfast wasn't good (Monterey breakfasts are very average), and there was only one light at one side for our double bed (which had to be pulled out from the wall). There was limited English spoken, so patience was needed. I'd highly recommend this hotel as a base for Tokyo.

The Hotel Monterey has a great location, right in the middle of Ginza. It is very reasonably priced, and has free in-room internet access. The rooms are rather small and pokey.The staff were nice and friendly, and I had no problems during the week of my stay.However, I didn't really like the place, and was glad to leave. You get what you pay for, and if there is ever a next time, I'll pay a little more to stay in a lighter, less "gloomy" building. But if you want to stay in the heart of Ginza, in a perfectly OK place at a bargain price, then the Monterey would be fine.

I'm VERY particular about cleanliness, and I have to say that this hotel was superb in terms of that. The bathroom (replete with a bidet--which you could choose to utilize or not) was immaculate, and I really appreciated that the comforter was zipped into this removable sheet that could be washed with every new guest (no more fear of touching the comforter). I guess I wasn't too crazy about just two things: The overlight was a bit too fluorescent for my taste, and the room had a lot of hard, uncomfortable furniture that didn't exactly invite you to just lounge after a tiring day shopping in Ginza. Please be advised that this hotel does not offer room service, which you probably won't need anyway, considering all the great eats around the area. The location is great. With one subway line, the Ginza It-chome, just a minute's walk away, and the main Ginza line about a 7-9 minute walk away, it was very convenient. I found that walking to the Ginza line directly allowed you to link up to the other arteries of the subway system easier, not to mention save you a bit of cash by avoiding numerous transfers. Overall, a good modern hotel.

Overall - a well located hotel at the heart of Ginza; near shops, subways and large range of restaurants from cheap eat to most expensive. Strong retro styled building that gives a business ‘boutique hotel’ feel (the lifts have sliding block indicator that actually click over each floor with a sound). Compact room size that offer adequate floor area for bags. Good size bath room for Japanese standards. No problem in returning for my next stay. Breakfast is expensive at the hotel, as expected in all Japanese hotels. More reasonable if you go for the local coffee shop - big mug of blended coffee at Y160. Service is attentive and staff spoke reasonable English. Check in / out time – disappointingly restrictive! Earliest check in time 3 PM and latest check out time by 11 AM with extra hour charge at Y1000. This is a ‘hard rule’ and typical of Japan hotels, even though there may be rooms available. Pretty stupid rules; Japan Travel Bureau please take note.Facilities - a compact hotel with few extra services. There is a large TV in the room with just one English Channel (BBC); access via a language selection that did not work well as the selected language kept reverting back to Japanese after some minutes. Internet access was free but you need to obtain a cable from the Reception (this practice is common in most Japan hotels). Coffee and tea are also supplied free of charge but the facilities are hidden away that you need to play hide and seek in finding them.Shakesp380, Sydney Australia

I booked a room for 3 people at the Monterey Ginza, the room rate was with Travelocity, clearly stating "3 ppl" on the room criteria, I noticed other Tokyo establishments through Travelocity stated clearly *2 ppl per room only*. At my dismay when checking in, the poor English speaking receptionist said the rooms were 2 people only, therefore I had to shell out for a single room for the 3rd person.The hotel welcoming area was cramped, crowded, although clearly well furnished given its 'new hotel' status. The restaurant was strictly of the businessman clientel, with prices to match. The rooms were small and snuggly (if you like that sort of thing), at least half the size of the average American hotel room. The bathroom included a nifty electronic 'spa' toilet and bidet, shame it didn't work properly, thankfully the manual chain did. Even the Lipton tea in the room is only 'accessible' via a fee.Clean hotel, pricey, well furnished, glossy, small, boutique style in a good location for the '$10 for a coffee' brigade in Ginza, Kanto. Watch out for the hidden extras and read the small print.
